{{Infobox company |name = GoMedia |logo = |type = Broadcast, mobile and OTT solutions |foundation = 2015 |parent = |location = [[Kings Cross, London]], England |key_people = Matt Seaman (Chief Executive}
Roger Matthews (Managing Director)
[[Bodo Linnhoff]] (Sales Director) |industry = Media & Telecoms |products = Onboard entertainment service, [[Video on demand]], [[Pay TV]] using BYOD |revenue = |homepage = }} '''GoMedia''' is a British company which supplies a management system which delivers entertainment packages including featuring films to travelers on trains and coaches including on [[Eurostar]] trains. The system also gives real-time travel information. Rather than using a monitor on the seat in front of the passenger, it uses the passenger's own device ("Bring Your Own Device" or BYOD) such as mobiles and tablets. It uses the vehicle's own [[wi-fi]] rather than the passenger's independent [[mobile network]] for on-board infotainment.[http://data.companieshouse.gov.uk/doc/company/09587265 Companies House extract company no 9587265] GoMedia Services Limited Their BEAM management system is the first app of its kind in the UK,{{cn|date=June 2018}} and is used across Virgin West Coast and East Coast. The films available include ''[[Independence Day]]'', which formed the foundation of Virgin Trains’ BEAM launch at Euston Station, London in late 2016. TV box sets from BBC Worldwide, cartoons, games, digital newspapers and magazines are also offered. The free[http://www.railwaygazette.com/news/technology/single-view/view/entertainment-on-demand-provided-on-virgin-trains-services.html www.railwaygazette.com;] ''Entertainment on demand provided on Virgin Trains services''; 09 Jun 2016; accessed 18 August 2016 on-demand entertainment provided includes films, [[catch-up TV]], box sets, cartoons, games, newspapers and magazines. A tracker app also shows the train's exact location. GoMedia have awarded the 'cloaking contract' to Irdeto, as well as the wi-fi's security, using their Secure Key Exchange.{{cite web|last1=Clover|first1=Julian|title=Bring your own device to Eurostar entertainment|url=http://www.broadbandtvnews.com/2016/03/16/bring-your-own-device-to-eurostar-entertainment/|website=Broadband TV News|publisher=Broadband TV News LLP|accessdate=31 March 2016}}{{cite web|title=Irdeto to protect Eurostar OTT video service|url=http://www.digitaltvnews.net/?p=27212|website=T.V. (digitaltvnews.net)|publisher=The Digital TV Consultancy|accessdate=31 March 2016}} Management includes chief executive Matt Seaman, managing director Roger Matthews, and Simon Dore.{{cite web|title=GoMedia taps Irdeto to ensure Eurostar OTT video delivery|url=http://www.rapidtvnews.com/2016031742148/gomedia-taps-irdeto-to-ensure-eurostar-ott-video-delivery.html#axzz44TQG3Mzf|website=Rapid TV News|publisher=Rapid TV News}} ==See also== {{Portal|Television}} *[[Hybrid Broadcast Broadband TV]] *[[List of digital distribution platforms for mobile devices]] *[[Over-the-top content]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Home theater PC (application software)}} [[Category:Streaming media systems]] [[Category:Information appliances]] [[Category:Film and video technology]] [[Category:Interactive television]] [[Category:Internet broadcasting]] [[Category:Internet television]] [[Category:Video on demand services]] [[Category:Multimedia]] [[Category:Peercasting]]

page.title: History of the oil shale industry

revision.comment: Rescuing 4 sources and tagging 1 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta2)
revision.text:
[[File:Production of oil shale.png|thumb|350px|right|Production of oil shale in millions of metric tons, from 1880 to 2010. Source: Pierre Allix, Alan K. Burnham.<ref name=oilfield> {{Cite journal | last1 = Allix | first1 = Pierre | last2 = Burnham | first2 = Alan K. | title = Coaxing Oil from Shale | journal = Oilfield Review | publisher = [[Schlumberger]] | date = 2010-12-01 | issue = 4 | volume = 22 | page = 6 | url= http://www.slb.com/~/media/Files/resources/oilfield_review/ors10/win10/coaxing.ashx | format = PDF | accessdate =2012-04-18}} </ref>]]
The '''history of the oil shale industry''' started in ancient times. The modern industrial use of [[oil shale]] for [[shale oil extraction|oil extraction]] dates to the mid-19th century and started growing just before [[World War I]] because of the mass production of automobiles and trucks and the supposed shortage of gasoline for transportation needs. Between the World Wars oil shale projects were begun in several countries.<ref name="wec-countries">[[#wec|Dyni (2010)]], pp. 103–122</ref>
After World War II, the [[oil shale industry]] declined due to increased accessibility to conventional [[petroleum|crude oil]]. As of 2010, oil shale was commercially used in [[Estonia]], [[China]] and [[Brazil]], while several countries are considering to start or restart commercial use of oil shale.<ref name="wec-countries"/>
==Early history== Humans have used oil shale as a fuel since prehistoric times, since it generally burns without any processing.<ref name=knutson87> {{cite conference | conference = 20th Oil Shale Symposium | location = [[Golden, Colorado]] | date = 21 April 1987 | last1 = Knutson | first1 = C.F. | last2 = Russell | first2 = P.L. | last3 = Dana | first3 = G.F. | title = Non-synfuel uses of oil shale}} </ref> It was also used for decorative purposes and construction. [[Britons (historical)|Britons]] of the [[Iron Age]] used to polish and form oil shale into ornaments.<ref name=west> {{cite web | last = West | first = Ian | title= Kimmeridge - The Blackstone - Oil Shale | publisher= [[University of Southampton]] | date=2008-01-06 | url = http://www.southampton.ac.uk/~imw/Kimmeridge-Oil-Shale.htm | accessdate=2014-08-31}} </ref> Around 3000 BC, "rock oil" was used in [[Mesopotamia]] for road construction and making architectural adhesives.<ref name=moody/>
As a decorative material, oil shale was also used over the [[Ancient Greece|Greek]], [[Roman Empire|Roman]], [[Byzantian Empire|Byzantinian]], [[Umayyad Caliphate|Umayyad]] and [[Abbasid Caliphate|Abbasid]] periods to decorate mosaics and floors of the palaces, churches and mosques.<ref name=Jordan> {{Cite journal |last1=Hamarneh |first1=Yousef |last2=Alali |first2=Jamal |last3=Sawaged |first3=Suzan |title=Oil Shale Resources Development In Jordan |location=Amman |publisher=Natural Resources Authority of Jordan |page=1 |year=2006 |url=http://www.nra.gov.jo/images/stories/pdf_files/Updated_Report_2006.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=2008-10-25 }}{{dead link|date=April 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} </ref><ref name=Bsieso> {{Cite conference | last = Bsieso | first = Munther S. | title = Oil Shale Resources Development In Jordan | conference = 26th Oil Shale Symposium | location = [[Golden, Colorado]] | publisher = [[Colorado School of Mines]] | pages = 4–5 | date = 2006-10-16 | url = http://www.ceri-mines.org/documents/Poster14-BsiesoJB2.pdf | format = PDF | accessdate =2009-05-30}} </ref>
[[Shale oil]] was used for medical and military purposes. Mesopotamians used it for medical purposes and for [[caulking]] ships, [[Mongol Empire|Mongols]] used to cap their arrows with flaming oil shale.<ref name=moody/> In the 10th century, the Arabian physician [[Masawaih al-Mardini]] (Mesue the Younger) described a method of extraction of oil from "some kind of bituminous shale".<ref name="art41">[[#art|Forbes (1970)]], pp. 41–42</ref> In the early 14th century, the first use of shale oil was recorded in Switzerland and Austria.<ref name="mushrush39"/><ref name=colorado> {{Cite journal | title = Oil Shale | publisher = [[Colorado School of Mines]] | year = 2008 | url = http://emfi.mines.edu/emfi2008/OilShale2008.pdf | format = PDF | accessdate =2011-05-06}} </ref> In 1350, a knight Berthold von Ebenhausen was awarded a right to exploit the Seefeld oil shale in Tyrol. Oil shale was used for production of shale oil using an early retorting method of heating the crushed oil shale put in [[crucible]]s.<ref name="art251">[[#art|Forbes (1970)]], p. 251</ref> The healing properties of a mineral oil distilled from [[oil shale]] were noted in 1596 by the personal physician of the [[Frederick I, Duke of Württemberg|Duke of Württemberg Frederick I]].<ref name=moody/>
In Skåne, the Swedish [[alum shale]] dating from the [[Cambrian]] and [[Ordovician]] periods was used for extracting potassium [[aluminium sulfate]] by roasting it over fire as early as 1637.<ref name="wec 118">[[#wec|Dyni (2010)]], p. 118</ref> In Italy, shale oil was used to light the streets of [[Modena]] at the turn of the 17th century.<ref name=moody/> The British Crown granted a patent in 1694 to three persons named Martin Eele, Thomas Hancock and William Portlock who had "found a way to extract and make great quantities of pitch, tarr, and oyle out of a sort of stone."<ref name=moody> {{Cite conference | last = Moody | first = Richard | title = UK Oil and Gas Shales—Definitions and Distribution in Time and Space | conference = History of On-Shore Hydrocarbon Use in the UK | url = https://www.geolsoc.org.uk/Groups-and-Networks/Specialist-Groups/History-of-Geology-Group/~/media/shared/documents/specialist%20and%20regional%20groups/hogg/hogg_weymouth%20abstract%20book.ashx | date = 2007-04-20 | pages = 1–2 | publisher = [[Geological Society of London]] | location = [[Weymouth, Dorset|Weymouth]] | accessdate = 2014-09-06}} </ref><ref name="mushrush39"/><ref name="yen56">[[#yen|Cane (1976)]], p. 56</ref><ref name=gallois/> Shale oil was produced by extracting [[Shropshire]] oil shale.<ref name="eu1">[[#eu|Francu ''et al.'' (2007)]], p. 1</ref> Later sold as Betton's British Oil, the distilled product was said to have been "tried by divers persons in Aches and Pains with much benefit."<ref name="art250">[[#art|Forbes (1970)]], p. 250</ref> In 1781, [[Archibald Cochrane, 9th Earl of Dundonald]], registered a patent for an extraction process to produce tar, pitch and oil from coal and bituminous shales, using masonry retorts and wooden condensers.<ref name="iom35">[[#iom|Addison ''et al.'' (1985)]], p. 35</ref>
In Russia [[Peter the Great]] initiated an investigative program of [[Ukhta]] oil shale in 1697. Data on physical and chemical properties of Ukhta oil shale was published by a correspondent member of the [[Russian Academy]] Tertii Bornovolokov in 1809.<ref name=pace/> In 1769, [[Peter Simon Pallas]] described oil shale of the [[Volga Region]].<ref name=lapidus> {{cite web | work = EnergyFuture.ru | url = http://energyfuture.ru/eto-prodolzhenie-stati-goryuchie-slancy-i-slancy-voobshhe-obzornaya-statya | script-title=ru:Горючие сланцы и сланцы вообще: обзорная статья |trans-title=Oil shale and shales in general: Review article (part 1) | last1 = Lapidus | first1 = A. L. | last2 = Strizhakova | first2 = Yu. A. | date = 2009-03-13 | accessdate = 2014-08-31 | language = Russian}} </ref> In the 1830s [[Germain Henri Hess]] investigated Baltic oil shales with resulting determination of the semicoking process product yields.<ref name=pace> {{cite journal |publisher = The Pace Company Consultants & Engineers |url = http://adr.coalliance.org/cog/fez/eserv/cog:2179/PACE_SFQR_V._19_N.1_1982.pdf |title = Direct Combustion of Oil Shale |journal = Pace Synthetic Fuels report |volume = 19 |issue = 1 |pages = 2–1 |format = PDF |date = March 1982 |accessdate = 2012-11-03 |id = {{subscription needed}} }}{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} </ref>
Oil shale in Australia was referred to for the first time by [[François Péron]], ''et al.'', in ''Voyage de Découverte aux Terres Australes''<ref name=peron> {{cite book |title=Voyage de Découverte aux Terres Australes |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=I_daAAAAQAAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false |first=François | last = Péron |publisher= l'Imprimerie impériale |location=Paris |year=1807}} </ref> which was published in [[Paris]] in 1807, describing what was probably torbanite from the [[Newnes, New South Wales|Newnes]] deposit.<ref name="kraemer4"/>
==Start of the modern industry== [[File:Kirk's Retort.png|thumb|right|250 px|alt=In this vertical [[retort]], oil shale is processed in a [[cast iron]] vessel which is broader at the bottom and narrow at the top. Lines on the left point to and describe its major components. From bottom to top, they consist of a water seal, coal-fired furnaces flanking a cast iron retort, a hopper receiving the shale, and a valve system. Arrows and text on the right show process inputs and outputs: steam is injected near the bottom of the retort; near its top, oil vapors and gases are drawn off and collected; a wheeled container delivers oil shale to the hopper.||[[Alexander Carnegie Kirk|Alexander C. Kirk's]] [[retort]], used in the mid-to-late 19th century, was one of the first vertical oil shale retorts. Its design is typical of retorts used in the end of the 19th and the beginning of the 20th century.<ref name="iom44">[[#iom|Addison ''et al.'' (1985)]], pp. 44–45</ref>]] [[File:West Lothian shale bing, Scotland.JPG|thumb|Three of West Lothian's shale bings - reminders of the industry pioneered in Scotland by [[James Young (Scottish chemist)|James "Paraffin" Young]].]] [[File:Shale Bing, Drumshoreland.jpg|thumb|The remains of a shale bing, Drumshoreland, near Pumpherston.]] The modern industrial use of oil shale for oil extraction started in France, where oil shale commercial mining began in [[Autun]] in 1837.<ref name=laherrere> {{Cite journal | last = Laherrère | first = Jean | title = Review on oil shale data | publisher = Hubbert Peak | year = 2005 | url = http://www.hubbertpeak.com/laherrere/OilShaleReview200509.pdf | format = PDF | accessdate = 2007-06-17}} </ref> The shale oil production started in 1838 by using Selligue process, invented by [[Alexander Selligue]].<ref name="iom35"/><ref name=Kansas/> In 1846 the Canadian physician and geologist [[Abraham Pineo Gesner|Abraham Gesner]] invented a process for retorting an illuminating liquid from coal, bitumen and oil shale.<ref name="nersesian124">[[#nersesian|Nersesian (2010)]], p. 124</ref><ref name="brill3">[[#brill|Forbes ''et al.'' (1957)]], p. 3</ref> In 1847 the Scottish chemist [[James Young (Scottish chemist)|James Young]] prepared "lighting oil," lubricating oil and wax from [[cannel coal]] and since 1862 from [[torbanite]].<ref name="yen235">[[#yen2|Prien (1976)]], p. 235</ref> In 1850 he patented the process of [[retorting]] and [[refining]] shale oil and purifying [[paraffin wax]] from it.<ref name="nersesian124"/><ref name="trass9">[[#trass|Trass (2011)]], p. 9</ref><ref name=gary> {{cite journal | publisher= [[Colorado School of Mines|Colorado School of Mines Press]] | editor = Gary, James H. | title = Twelfth Oil Shale Symposium Proceedings | date = August 1979}} </ref> Commercial scale shale oil extraction from [[lamosite]] started in 1859 by Robert Bell in [[Broxburn, West Lothian]].<ref name="iom35"/> In After expiring of Young's patent in 1862 many small shale oil works were opened.<ref name=museum/> By 1865, there were about 120 shale oil works in Scotland.<ref name=gallois/> In 1866 Young established Young's Paraffin Light and Mineral Oil Company at [[Addiewell]]. Other notable shale oil companies were the Broxburn Oil Company established in 1878 and the Pumpherston Oil Company established in 1892.<ref name=museum/>
In the United States early oil-shale industry concentrated on the eastern oil shale deposits.<ref name="epa-c-1"/> An oil distillery was built in 1855 at [[Breckinridge County, Kentucky]] to produce oil from locally mined [[cannel coal]]. By the following year it was producing {{convert|600|to|700|USgal/d|m3/d|1}}. In 1860, there were 55 companies in the United States extracting oil from locally mined cannel coal.<ref name="ashley42">[[#ashley|Ashley (1918)]], pp. 42–43</ref> Commercial-scale shale oil extraction, other than cannel coal processing, began at shale oil retorts using the [[Devonian]] oil shale along the [[Ohio River Valley]] in 1857.<ref name=Kansas> {{cite journal |title = Oil Shale in Kansas |last1 = Runnels | first1 = Russell T. |last2 = Kulstad | first2 = Robert O. |last3 = McDuffee | first3 = Clinton |last4 = Schleicher | first4 = John A. |journal= Kansas Geological Survey Bulletin |issue = 96, part 3 |year = 1952 |publisher= University of Kansas Publications |url= http://www.kgs.ku.edu/Publications/Bulletins/96_3/index.html |accessdate=2009-05-30}} </ref> However, the discovery of cheap and abundant petroleum in the same region, starting with the [[Drake Oil Well]] at [[Titusville, Pennsylvania]] in 1859, put the American oil shale industry out of business by 1860.<ref name=britannica/><ref name="assessment110">[[#assessment|OTA (1980)]], p. 110</ref> The largest deposit, [[Green River Formation]], was accidentally discovered in 1874 but not utilized until beginning of the 20th century.<ref name=gallois> {{Cite journal | journal = Journal of the Institution of Petroleum Technologists | publisher = [[New Scientist]] | title= What price oil shales? | pages = 490–493 | first = Ramues | last = Gallois | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QFemJs_jlvcC&pg=PA492&lpg=PA490 | date = 1978-02-23 | volume = 77 | issue = 1091 | issn = 0262-4079}} </ref>
In 1857, oil shale industry started in Germany.<ref name="assessment109">[[#assessment|OTA (1980)]], p. 109</ref> In Canada, the Craigleith Shale Oil Works started to retort oil shale of the [[Ordovician]] Whitby Formation near [[Collingwood, Ontario]], on [[Lake Huron]] in 1859.<ref name=seattle> {{Cite conference | last1 = Barker | first1 = J.F. | last2 = Dickhout | first2 = D. | last3 = Russell | first3 = D.J. | last4 = Johnson | first4 = M.D. | last5 = Gunther | first5 = P.R. | title = The organic geochemistry of the Ordovician Whitby Formation – a possible Ontario shale | conference = Symposium on Geochemistry and Chemistry of Oil Shale | location = [[Seattle]] | url= http://web.anl.gov/PCS/acsfuel/preprint%20archive/Files/28_3_SEATTLE_03-83_0039.pdf | format = PDF | date = 1983-03-20 | accessdate =2009-05-30}} </ref><ref name=encarta1> {{cite journal | title = Craigleith Oil Shale Works, Ontario | journal = Petroleum History Society Archives | date = March 2007 | volume = 18 | issue = 2 | pages = 4–6 | url = http://www.petroleumhistory.ca/archivesnews/2007/03Mar/phs07-03.pdf | format = PDF | accessdate = 2014-08-31}} </ref> In 1861 it became economically infeasible due to the discovery of petroleum nearby.<ref name=britannica> {{Cite web |title = Oil shale: History of oil shale use |url = http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/426232/oil-shale/308301/Upgrading#toc50639 |publisher= [[Encyclopædia Britannica]] |accessdate=2014-09-06}} </ref>
In Australia, the first oil shale mine was commenced in 1865 at American Creek, [[Mount Kembla]] in [[New South Wales]]. At the same year, the first shale oil was produced by the Pioneer Kerosene Works at American Creek.<ref name="kraemer4">[[#kraemer|Kraemer ''et al.'' (1951)]], p. 4</ref><ref name=pioneer> {{cite web | first = Michael | last = Organ | authorlink = Michael Organ | url= http://www.uow.edu.au/~morgan/oilshale.htm | title = The Pioneer Kerosene Works at American Creek, Mount Kembla, New South Wales | accessdate=2009-07-17}} </ref> A number of other mines and shale oil plants were opened in New South Wales; however, in the beginning of the 20th century they were closed due to the import of cheaper crude oil.<ref name="kraemer6">[[#kraemer|Kraemer ''et al.'' (1951)]], pp. 6–7</ref>
In Austria, oil shale was used in 1840–1882 for production of [[asphalt mastic]], [[naphtha]] and asphalt tar.<ref name="epa-c-4"/> In Sweden, the first attempt to extract oil from alum shale was made in 1864.<ref name=ekberg> {{Cite web | title = Ekeby historia |trans-title=History of Ekeby | last1 = Ekberg |first1 = Göran | url= http://www.gorek.se/skriftx/ssab.pdf | format= PDF | language = Swedish | accessdate=2014-09-06}} </ref> Shale oil production started in the 1890s and lasted few years.<ref name=ekberg/><ref name="wec96">[[#wec|Dyni (2010)]], p. 96</ref> In Brazil, oil shale was first exploited in 1884 in [[Bahia]].<ref name="wec105">[[#wec|Dyni (2010)]], pp. 105–106</ref> In 1900 shale oil extraction industry was initiated also in New Zealand.<ref name=britannica/>
In 1894, the [[Pumpherston retort]] (also known as the Bryson retort) was invented, which is considered as a separation of the oil shale industry from the coal industry.<ref name="iom38">[[#iom|Addison ''et al.'' (1985)]], p. 38</ref> It stayed in use until 1938.<ref name=combustion> {{Cite conference | title=A method of reducing CO<sub>2</sub> emissions from oil shale retorting | last1=Coates |first1=Ralph L. | last2= Hatfield | first2 = Kent E. | last3 = Smoot | first3 = L. Douglas | publisher= [[Colorado School of Mines]] | conference = 27th Oil Shale Symposium | location = [[Golden, Colorado]] | url= http://www.ceri-mines.org/documents/27symposium/presentations/av15-4coates.pdf | format= PDF | date= 2007-10-17 | accessdate=2009-05-30}} </ref>
Operations during the 19th century focused on the production of [[kerosene]], [[lamp oil]], and [[paraffin wax]]; these products helped supply the growing demand for lighting that arose during the [[Industrial Revolution]].<ref name=encarta2> {{cite web |title=Petroleum |first=Todd M. |last=Doscher |publisher=[[MSN Encarta]] |accessdate=2008-04-22 |url=http://encarta.msn.com/encyclopedia_761576221/petroleum.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080512122018/http://encarta.msn.com/encyclopedia_761576221/petroleum.html |archivedate=2008-05-12}} </ref> Fuel oil, lubricating oil and grease, and [[ammonium sulfate]] were also produced.<ref> {{cite web |url=http://emd.aapg.org/technical_areas/oil_shale.cfm |title=Oil Shale |publisher= [[American Association of Petroleum Geologists]] |accessdate=2008-03-31}} </ref>
==Beginning of the 20th century== [[File:Kilvebrickretort.jpg|thumb|Oil retort at [[Kilve]], [[West Somerset]], England]] [[File:Pumpherston Retorts.png|left|thumb|Pumpherston oil shale retorts, Scotland, 1922]]
The oil shale industry expanded immediately before World War I because of limited access to conventional petroleum resources and the mass production of automobiles and trucks, which accompanied an increase in gasoline consumption.<ref name=informationcenter/> Oil shale production in Scotland peaked in 1910–1912 with more than three million tonnes.<ref name=gallois/> That time Scottish shale oil industry contributed 2% of global oil production.<ref name=museum/> After that, production declined with exception of the period of [[World War II]].<ref name=gallois/> In 1919, five survived shale oil companies (''Young's Paraffin Light & Mineral Oil Company'', ''Broxburn Oil Company'', ''Pumpherston Shale Oil Company'', ''Oakbank Oil Company'', and ''James Ross & Company Philpstoun Oil Works''), were merged into Scottish Oils, a subsidiary of [[Anglo-Persian Oil Company]].<ref name=museum> {{cite web | title = A Brief History of the Scottish Shale Oil Industry | work = Museum of the Scottish Shale Oil Industry | url = http://www.scottishshale.co.uk/HistoryPages/index.html | accessdate = 2012-07-07}} </ref><ref name=ferrier177>[[#ferrier|Bamberg ''et al.'' (1994)]], p. 177</ref><ref name=marwick175>[[#marwick|Marwick (1964)]], p. 175</ref><ref name=uphall>{{cite web|title=Scottish Oils|publisher=Uphall On The Web|url=http://uphall.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=116&Itemid=128|accessdate=2012-07-07}}</ref>
[[File:Oil Shale Retorts Nevada.png|thumb|Oil shale retorts, Nevada, 1922]] In the United States the government started to create the [[Naval Petroleum and Oil Shale Reserves]] in 1909.<ref name=fossilenergyA2/> The reserves were seen as a possible emergency source of fuel for the military, particularly the [[United States Navy|Navy]].<ref name=informationcenter> {{cite web | publisher= Environmentally Conscious Consumers for Oil Shale | url= http://www.eccos.us/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=17&Itemid=13 | title = History | accessdate=2011-05-06}} </ref> The government reserved the [[Roan Plateau]] near [[Rifle, Colorado]] which later became a federal demonstration and test site.<ref name=informationcenter/> First attempt to produce oil from the western deposits was made in Nevada by local businessman Robert Catlin by acquiring oil-shale properties in the 1890s and erecting the first retorts in 1915 and 1916. Although the attempt was commercially unsuccessful, in 1917 he incorporated Catlin Shale Products Company which made several unsuccessful attempts to sold shale oil products until it was dissolved in 1930.<ref name="epa-c-1">[[#epa|EPA (1979)]], pp. C-1–C-2</ref> The first attempts to exploit the Green River Formation deposit was made by establishment of The Oil Shale Mining Company in 1916.<ref name="epa-c-1"/> In 1917, they erected the first commercial retort at the head of Dry Creek, near [[De Beque, Colorado]].<ref name=mehls> {{cite book | title = The Valley of Opportunity: A History of West-Central Colorado | year = 1982 | first = Steven F. | last = Mehls | work = [[Bureau of Land Management]] | series = Colorado Cultural Resources Series | issue = 12 | url = http://www.nps.gov/history/history/online_books/blm/cultresser/co/12/chap11.htm | isbn = 9781496015587}} </ref> However, also these attempts were unsuccessful and by 1926 the company had lost its property.<ref name="epa-c-1"/> In addition, companies like [[Cities Service]], [[Standard Oil of California]], [[Texaco]] and [[Unocal Corporation|Union]] started their oil shale operations in 1918–1920.<ref name="epa-c-1"/> In 1915–1920 about 200 companies were established to exploit oil shale and at least 25 shale oil retorting processes reached to the pilot-plant stage. [[Texas Oil Boom|Discoveries of the large quantities of petroleum in eastern Texas]] ended the oil-shale boom.<ref name="assessment110"/> One of technological achievements before World War II was invention of the [[Nevada–Texas–Utah Retort|N-T-U retort]]. In 1925, the NTU Company built a test plant at Sherman Cut near [[Casmalia, California]].<ref name="assessment139"/><ref name=petroleum> {{Cite journal | journal = Journal of the Institution of Petroleum Technologists | publisher = [[Institute of Petroleum|Institution of Petroleum Technologists]] | title= California, Oil Shale, Progress in 1925 | page = 371 | url= https://books.google.com/books?id=VQA4AAAAMAAJ&q=Sherman+Cut+oil+shale+NTU+retort&dq=Sherman+Cut+oil+shale+NTU+retort | year = 1926 | volume = 12}} </ref> In 1925–1929, the retort was also tested by the [[United States Bureau of Mines]] in their Oil Shale Experiment Station at Anvil Point in Rifle, Colorado.<ref name="epa-c-1"/><ref name="assessment139"/><ref name="utah373">[[#utah|Carter ''et al.'' (1939)]], p. 373</ref>
During [[World War I]], the [[German Army (German Empire)|German Army]] produced shale oil from the [[Oil shale in Jordan|Jordan oil shale]] at the Yarmouk area to operate the [[Hejaz Railway]].<ref name=Jordan/><ref name=alali> {{Cite conference |last = Alali |first = Jamal |title = Jordan Oil Shale, Availability, Distribution, And Investment Opportunity |location = [[Amman]], [[Jordan]] |conference = International Oil Shale Conference |url = http://www.sdnp.jo/International_Oil_Conference/rtos-A117.pdf |format = PDF |date = 2006-11-07 |accessdate = 2008-10-25 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20080527234121/http://www.sdnp.jo/International_Oil_Conference/rtos-A117.pdf |archive-date = 2008-05-27 |dead-url = yes |df = }} </ref> In 1915 an oil shale industry was established in Switzerland.<ref name="mushrush39">[[#mushrush|Mushrush (1995)]], p. 39</ref><ref name=britannica/> About 1920, a small mall shale oil extraction plant was opened at [[Kinnekulle]], Sweden.<ref name="epa-c-9"/> In 1922, a small shale oil extraction plant was opened in [[Puertollano]], Spain.<ref name="epa-c-9">[[#epa|EPA (1979)]], p. C-9</ref>
The year 1916 is considered the beginning of the Estonian oil shale industry.<ref name="kukersiteOS 3">[[#kukersiteOS|Aaloe et al. (2007)]], p. 3</ref> when a group of geologists, led by [[Nikolay Pogrebov]], was sent to Estonia to organise the mining of oil shale and its transportation to [[Saint Petersburg]] (then known as Petrograd). In June 1916, the first tonnes of oil shale were mined at Pavandu and delivered to [[Saint Petersburg Polytechnical University]] for large-scale experiments.<ref name=kogerman> {{Cite journal | last = Kogerman | first = Aili | title = Editor's Page | journal = Oil Shale. A Scientific-Technical Journal | publisher = Estonian Academy Publishers | volume = 20 | issue = 1 | pages =1–2 | year =2003 | url= http://www.kirj.ee/public/oilshale/1_ed_page_1_03.pdf | format = PDF | issn = 0208-189X | accessdate =2008-10-25}} </ref> In 1917, Russian [[paleontologist]] Mikhail Zalessky named kukersite oil shale after the Kukruse settlement.<ref name=lille> {{Cite journal | last =Lille | first =Ü | title =Current knowledge on the origin and structure of Estonian kukersite kerogen | journal =Oil Shale. A Scientific-Technical Journal | publisher = Estonian Academy Publishers | volume = 20 | issue =3 | pages =253–263 | year =2003 | url=http://www.kirj.ee/public/oilshale/3_lille_2003_3.pdf | format = PDF | issn = 0208-189X | accessdate =2008-10-25}} </ref> Continuous mining activities started shortly after.<ref name="kukersiteOS 21">[[#kukersiteOS|Aaloe et al. (2007)]], p. 21</ref> Initially, oil shale was used primarily in the cement industry, for firing in locomotive furnaces, and as a household fuel, followed by shale oil and power production.<ref name="ots 15"/> As of 1925, all locomotives in Estonia were powered by oil shale.<ref name="holmberg 94">[[#holmberg|Holmberg (2008)]], p. 94</ref> The first experimental oil shale processing [[retort]]s were built in 1921, using the method developed by [[Julius Pintsch AG]].<ref name="ots 15"/><ref name=teknisk> {{Cite journal | last = Lindquist | first = W. | title = Estländska oljeskifferindustrien |trans-title=Estonian oil shale industry | journal = [[Teknisk Tidskrift]]. Kemi | issue = 9 | pages = 71–75 | date = 1937-09-11 | url= http://runeberg.org/tektid/1937k/0075.html | language = Swedish | accessdate =2014-03-31}} </ref> In 1924, the [[Tallinn Power Plant]] was the first power plant in the world to employ oil shale as its primary fuel.<ref name="ots 15">[[#ots2|Ots (2004)]], pp. 15–16</ref><ref name=arvoots> {{Cite journal | last =Ots | first =Arvo | title =Estonian oil shale properties and utilization in power plants | journal = Energetika | publisher = Lithuanian Academy of Sciences Publishers | volume = 53 | issue = 2 | pages = 8–18 | date = 2007-02-12 | url= http://www.e-biblioteka.lt/resursai/LMA/Energetika/2007_2/4.pdf | format = PDF | accessdate =2011-05-06}} </ref> In 1939 Estonia mined 1.453 million tonnes of oil shale and produced 181,000 tonnes of shale oil, including 22,500 tonnes of oil that were suitable gasoline equivalents.<ref name=uibopuu> {{Cite journal |last1=Uibopuu |first1=Lembit |title=Saksa kapital Eesti põlevkivitööstuses (1922–1940) ja Eesti põlevkivitööstus Saksa okupatsiooni ajal (1941–1944) |trans-title=The German capital in Estonian oil shale industry (1922–1940) and the Estonian oil shale industry during the German occupation (1941–1944) |publisher=[[Tallinn University of Technology]] |url=http://www.ene.ttu.ee/maeinstituut/seminar/saksakapitaleestis.htm |language=Estonian |accessdate=2014-04-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141026145106/http://www.ene.ttu.ee/maeinstituut/seminar/saksakapitaleestis.htm |archivedate=2014-10-26 |df= }} </ref> Almost half of Estonian produced shale oil was exported accounting for 8% of country's total export.<ref name=ttu/>
In China, the extraction of oil shale began in 1926 under the Japanese rule.<ref name="dyni15">[[#dyni|Dyni (2006)]], p. 15</ref> The commercial-scale production of shale oil began in 1930 in Fushun, [[Manchuria]], with the construction of the "Refinery No. 1" operating [[Fushun process|Fushun-type retorts]].<ref name="dyni13">[[#dyni|Dyni (2006)]], p. 13</ref> In Russia, Kashpirskoye oil shale near [[Syzran]] in the Volga region was mined and processed in 1919–1924 and again starting from 1929.<ref name=lapidus/> [[Leningradslanets]] opened the Kirov oil shale mine in 1934 in [[Slantsy, Leningrad Oblast]] and shale oil production started in 1939. Saratov and Syzran power stations in Russia started to use oil shale as fuel.<ref name=lapidus/> In South Africa different attempts of using oil shale were made since beginning of century. In 1903 the Transvaal Oil Shale Syndicate investigated oil shale at Kikvorschfontein. In 1919–1931 the African Oil Corporation investigated oil shale at Kromhoek and [[Goedgevonden]]. In 1935, The South African Torbanite Mining and Refining Company, a joint venture of Anglo-Transvaal Consolidated Investment Company and [[Burmah Oil]] opened shale oil plant at [[Ermelo, Mpumalanga|Ermelo]] in 1935.<ref name="kraemer2-4">[[#kraemer2|Kraemer ''et al.'' (1954)]], p. 4</ref>
Between the World Wars oil shale projects were also in restarted in Brazil and, for a short time, in Canada.<ref name="wec105"/>
==World War II== In 1939–1945, a shale oil pilot plant operated in [[Morocco]].<ref name="wec116">[[#wec|Dyni (2010)]], p. 116</ref> In Australia shale oil production restarted shortly before World War II. In 1937, the ''National Oil Proprietary'' was created. The [[Glen Davis Shale Oil Works]] became operational at [[Glen Davis, New South Wales]] in 1940 as the main facility in the country.<ref name="epa-c-4">[[#epa|EPA (1979)]], p. C-4</ref><ref name="kraemer11">[[#kraemer|Kraemer ''et al.'' (1951)]], p. 11</ref> In addition, in 1940–1952, three N-T-U retorts were operated at Marangaroo, [[New South Wales]].<ref name="assessment139">[[#assessment|OTA (1980)]], p. 139</ref><ref name=coal1> {{Cite journal | last = Prien | first = Charles H. | title= Pyrolysis of Coal and Shale | journal = Industrial and Engineering Chemistry | publisher = [[American Chemical Society]] | version = 43 | issue = 9 | pages = 2006–2015 | year = 1951 | doi = 10.1021/ie50501a022 | volume = 43}} </ref><ref name=petroleum2>[[#petroleum2|Mapstone (1950)]], p. 489</ref>
In Sweden, ''Svenska skifferolje AB'' (Swedish Shale Oil Company) was formed in 1940.<ref name="yen236">[[#yen2|Prien (1976)]], p. 236</ref> It exploited one of the earliest ''in-situ'' processes–underground gasification by electrical energy ([[Fredrik Ljungström|Ljungström]] method)–between 1940 and 1966 at [[Kumla Municipality|Kvarntorp]].<ref name="assessment108">[[#assessment|OTA (1980)]], pp. 108–109</ref>
During the [[German occupation of Estonia during World War II|German occupation of Estonia]], Estonia's oil shale industry was merged into a company named ''Baltische Öl GmbH''. This entity was subordinated to ''[[Kontinentale Öl]]'', a company that had exclusive rights to oil production in [[German-occupied Europe|German-occupied territories]].<ref name=uibopuu/><ref name="holmberg 130">[[#holmberg|Holmberg (2008)]], pp. 130–131</ref> The primary purpose of the industry was production of oil for the [[German Army (Wehrmacht)|German Army]].<ref name="holmberg 130"/>
In Germany shale oil extraction started at the [[Dotternhausen]] cement factory in 1940.<ref name="epa-c-6">[[#epa|EPA (1979)]], p. C-6</ref> Later the [[Operation Desert (German fuel project)|Operation Desert (''Unternehmen Wüste'')]] was launched for the oil extraction from [[Swabian Alb]] oil shale deposits ([[Posidonia Shale]]). However, out of ten planned shale-oil extraction plants only four became operational. The used modified ''in-situ'' process was primitive with extremely low oil recovery and it was hard to control.<ref name="assessment133">[[#assessment|OTA (1980)]], p. 133</ref>
In 1944 the United States adopted the [[Synthetic Liquid Fuels Program]] with goal to establish a liquid fuel supply from domestic oil shale. The Bureau of Mines started mining studies and development of the [[gas combustion retort process]] at Anvil Point.<ref name="assessment110"/> In 1943 [[Mobil Oil]] built a pilot shale oil extraction plant and in 1944 Union built an experimental oil shale retort. In 1945 Texaco started shale oil refining study.<ref name="epa-c-1"/>
==1950s–1960s== [[File:ANVIL POINTS RESEARCH CENTER, A GOVERNMENT FACILITY, HAS BEEN LEASED TO DEVELOPMENT ENGINEERING INC. WHICH WILL TEST... - NARA - 552544.jpg|thumb|Anvils Point Research Center in 1970.]] Although the Estonian, Russian and Chinese oil shale industries continued to grow after World War II, most other countries abandoned their projects due to high processing costs and the availability of cheaper petroleum.<ref name="wec-countries"/><ref name=laherrere/> The shale oil extraction in Australia was discontinued in 1952 due to ceasing of government funding, in France in 1957, in Britain and South Africa in 1962, and in Sweden and Spain in 1966.<ref name="yen236"/><ref name="wec-ceased">[[#wec|Dyni (2010)]], pp. 103; 110; 118</ref> In Germany only Rohrbach Zement (now part of [[Holcim]]) in [[Dotternhausen]] continued using oil shale for cement, power and thermal energy production.<ref name="wec110">[[#wec|Dyni (2010)]], p. 110</ref>
After World War II, the [[Occupation of the Baltic states|Soviet occupation regime]] restored the [[oil shale industry in Estonia]]. In 1945, the first tunnel kiln was restored and by the end of the 1940s four tunnel kilns had been restored. German prisoners of war contributed most of the labour.<ref name="holmberg 134">[[#holmberg|Holmberg (2008)]], pp. 134; 293</ref> In addition to tunnel kilns a number of [[Kiviter]]-type retorts and the first [[Galoter]]-type retort were built in the 1950s.<ref name="ots 15"/> Since 1948, Estonian-produced [[oil shale gas]] was used in Leningrad (Saint Petersburg) and in northern Estonia cities as a substitute for natural gas.<ref name=ttu> {{Cite web | first = Ingo | last = Valgma | title = Map of oil shale mining history in Estonia | publisher = [[Tallinn University of Technology]] | url = http://www.ene.ttu.ee/maeinstituut/mgis/mapofhistory.htm | accessdate = 2008-10-25 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140817092025/http://www.ene.ttu.ee/maeinstituut/mgis/mapofhistory.htm | archivedate = 2014-08-17 | deadurl = no}} </ref><ref name=alekperov>[[#alekperov|Alekperov (2011)]], p. 146</ref><ref name=vkg> {{cite web | publisher= [[Viru Keemia Grupp]] | url= http://www.vkg.ee/?id=1947 | title = History of the company | accessdate=2007-07-21}} </ref> During the 1950s, unsuccessful tests of oil shale underground gasification were conducted at [[Kiviõli]].<ref name=vali> {{Cite journal | last1 = Väli | first1 = E. | last2 = Valgma | first2 = I. | last3 = Reinsalu | first3 = E. | title = Usage of Estonian oil shale | journal = [[Oil Shale (journal)|Oil Shale. A Scientific-Technical Journal]] | publisher = [[Estonian Academy Publishers]] | volume = 25 | issue = 2 | pages =101–114 | year =2008 | url= http://www.kirj.ee/public/oilshale_pdf/2008/issue_2S/oil-2008-2S-2.pdf | format = PDF | issn = 0208-189X | accessdate =2008-10-25 | doi =10.3176/oil.2008.2S.02}} </ref><ref name=pitin> {{Cite journal | last1 = Pitin | first1 = R. N. | last2 = Sporius | first2 = A. E. | last3 = Farberov | first3 = I. L. | title = First Experiment in Underground Treatment of Oil Shale Without Shaft | journal= Trudy Instituta Goryuchikh Ispokaemykh | publisher= [[Academy of Sciences of the USSR]] | pages=44–60 | year=1957 | volume = 7 | language = Russian}}</ref><ref name="eu 8">[[#eu|Francu ''et al''. (2007)]], p. 8</ref> In 1946–1952, [[uranium compounds]] were extracted from [[Graptolitic argillite]] oil shale in [[Sillamäe]].<ref name="dyni17">[[#dyni|Dyni (2006)]], p. 17</ref><ref name=lippmaa> {{Cite journal | last1 = Lippmaa | first1 = E. | last2 = Maremäe | first2 = E. | title = Uranium production from the local Dictyonema shale in North-East Estonia | journal = Oil Shale. A Scientific-Technical Journal | publisher = Estonian Academy Publishers | volume = 17 | issue = 4 | pages = 387–394 | year =2000 | issn = 0208-189X }}</ref><ref name=maremae> {{Cite journal | last = Maremäe | first = E. | title = Extraction of uranium from local Dictyonema shale at Sillamäe in 1948–1952 | journal =Oil Shale. A Scientific-Technical Journal | publisher = Estonian Academy Publishers | volume = 18 | issue = 3 | pages = 259–271 | year =2001 | issn = 0208-189X}} </ref> In 1949, the Kohtla-Järve Power Plant – the first power plant in the world using pulverized oil shale at an industrial scale – was commissioned in Estonia.<ref name="ots 15"/> The world's two largest oil shale-fired power stations – Balti Power Plant and Eesti Power Plant (known as the [[Narva Power Plants]]) – were opened in 1965 and in 1973.<ref name="wec 108">[[#wec|Dyni (2010)]], p. 108</ref> In 1965, {{convert|510|e6m3}} of oil shale gas were produced and 16.5 million tonnes of oil shale were mined in Estonia.<ref name="holmberg 140">[[#holmberg|Holmberg (2008)]], p. 140</ref>
In Russia, the [[Zavod Slantsy|Slantsy oil shale gas extraction plant]] was built for supplying oil shale gas to Leningrad and the first unit of the Slantsy oil-shale-fired power plant were commissioned in 1952.<ref name=alekperov/><ref name=slantsy> {{Cite web |script-title = ru:История |trans-title = History |publisher = [[Zavod Slantsy]] |url = http://www.slantsy.ru/company/story/ |accessdate = 2012-10-30 |language = Russian |title = Archived copy |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20121105093257/http://www.slantsy.ru/company/story/ |archive-date = 2012-11-05 |dead-url = yes |df = }} </ref> Since 1955 until 2003, the plant also produced shale oil using Kiviter technology.<ref name=15maegs> {{Cite conference | author = Leivernen, Jussi| title = Modelling impacts of oil-shale mining on groundwater resources in the Slantsy region, Russia | conference = 15th Meeting of the Association of European Geological Societies | publisher = Institute of Geology at Tallinn University of Technology | url= http://www.gi.ee/maegs15/presentations/3_3_Leveinen.ppt | format = PDF | date = 2007-09-16 | location = Tallinn | accessdate =2012-10-30|display-authors=etal}} </ref>
In China, the "Refinery No. 2" of Fushun began its production in 1954 and in 1959, the maximum annual shale oil production increased to 780,000 tonnes.<ref name="dyni13"/><ref name=qian2> {{Cite conference | last1 = Qian | first1 = Jialin | last2 = Wang | first2 = Jianqiu | last3 = Li | first3 = Shuyuan | title = Oil Shale Activity in China | conference = 26th Oil Shale Symposium | publisher = [[Colorado School of Mines]] | url= http://www.ceri-mines.org/A02c-JialinQianpaper.pdf.pdf | format = PDF | year = 2006 | accessdate =2008-10-25}} </ref><ref name=china/> The produced shale oil was used for producing light liquid fuels.<ref name=china> {{Cite journal | last1 = Qian | first1 = Jialin | last2 = Wang | first2 = Jianqiu | last3 = Li | first3 = Shuyuan | title = Oil Shale Development in China | journal = Oil Shale. A Scientific-Technical Journal | publisher = Estonian Academy Publishers | volume = 20 | issue = 3 | pages = 356–359 | year = 2003 | url = http://www.kirj.ee/public/oilshale/9_qian_2003_3s.pdf | format = PDF | issn = 0208-189X | accessdate = 2008-10-25}} </ref> In 1961, China was producing one third of its total oil production from oil shale.<ref name=laherrere/> Afterwards the shale oil production decreased due to the discovery of [[Daqing oil field]] and increased production of the cheaper conventional petroleum.<ref name=china/>
In 1951, the [[United States Department of Defense]] became interested in oil shale as an alternative resource for producing a jet fuel.<ref name=andrews9>[[#andrews|Andrews (2006)]], p. 9</ref> The United States Bureau of Mines continued its research program at Anvil Point until 1956.<ref name="assessment110"/> It opened a demonstration mine which operated at a small scale.<ref name=informationcenter/> From 1949 to 1955 it also tested the gas combustion retort.<ref name="assessment140">[[#assessment|OTA (1980)]], p. 140</ref> In 1964 the Avril Point demonstration facility was leased by [[Colorado School of Mines]] and was used by Mobil-led consortium (Mobil, [[Humble Oil|Humble]], [[Continental Oil|Continental]], [[Amoco]], [[Phillips Petroleum Company|Phillips]] and [[Sinclair Oil Corporation|Sinclair]]) for further development of that type of retort.<ref name="epa-c-1"/><ref name="assessment110"/> In 1953, [[Sinclair Oil Corporation]] developed an ''[[in-situ]]'' processing method using existing and induced fractures between vertical wells.<ref name=lee124>[[#lee|Lee (1990)]], p. 124</ref> In the 1960s, a proposal known as Project Bronco, was suggested for a modified ''in situ'' process which involved creation of a rubble chimney (a zone in the rock formation created by breaking the rock into fragments) using a [[nuclear explosive]].<ref name=chimney> {{Cite journal | last1 = Lombard | first1 = D.B. | last2 = Carpenter | first2 = H.C. | title = Recovering Oil by Retorting a Nuclear Chimney in Oil Shale | journal = Journal of Petroleum Technology | volume = 19 | publisher = Society of Petroleum Engineers | pages = 727–734 | issue = 19 | year = 1967 | doi = 10.2118/1669-PA | issn = 0149-2136 | id = SPE-1669-PA}} </ref> This plan was abandoned by the [[United States Atomic Energy Commission|Atomic Energy Commission]] in 1968.<ref name=fossilenergyA2/> Companies developing experimental ''in-situ'' retorting processes also included Equity Oil, [[ARCO]], [[Shell Oil]] and the Laramie Energy Technology Center.<ref name="epa-c-1"/>
[[Unocal Corporation]] started the development of the [[Union process]] in the late 1940s, when the Union A retort was designed.<ref name=merrow107>[[#rand3|Merrow (1978)]], p. 107</ref> This technology was tested between 1954 and 1958 at the company-owned tract in the Parachute Creek.<ref name=BLM2008appendix15>[[#BLM2008appendix|BLM (2008)]], p. A-15</ref><ref name=dhondt> {{Cite conference | conference = Synthetic Fuels–Status and Directions | publisher = Electric Power research Institute | last1 = Dhondt | first1 = R.O. | last2 = Duir | first2 = J.H. | pages = 16{{hyphen}}1{{ndash}}16{{hyphen}}23<!-- this is a page number format and range, please do not replace hyphens with n-dash --> | url= http://www.fischer-tropsch.org/DOE/_conf_proc/Electric%20Power%20Research/81903476/de81903476_sec16.pdf | format = PDF | date = 13–16 October 1980 | title = Union Oil's Shale Oil Demonstration Plant | accessdate=2009-10-03 | isbn = }} </ref> This production was finally shut down in 1961 due to cost.<ref name=fossilenergyA2/><ref name=andrews9/> In 1957 Texaco built a shale oil extraction pilot plant to develop its own [[hydroretorting process]].<ref name="epa-c-1"/> In the early 1960s [[Tosco Corporation|TOSCO (The Oil Shale Corporation)]] opened an underground mine and built an experimental plant near [[Parachute, Colorado]]. It was closed in 1972 because the price of production exceeded the cost of imported crude oil.<ref name=laherrere/><ref name=Alberta> {{Cite journal | last = Chandler | first = Graham | title = US eyes Alberta as model for developing oil shale | journal =Alberta Oil | volume = 2 | issue =4 | pages = 16–18 | year = 2006 | url = http://www.albertaoilmagazine.com/2006/10/us-eyes-alberta/ | accessdate = 2014-09-07}} </ref>
==1970s–1980s== [[File:THE COLONY PLANT (NEAR GRAND VALLEY IN THE PICEANCE BASIN) AFTER YEARS OF RESEARCH, HAS TAKEN OIL SHALE FROM AN... - NARA - 552686.jpg|thumb|The Colony oil shale development site in August 1973.]]
Due to the [[1973 oil crisis]], the oil shale industry restarted in several countries. The United States Navy and the Office of Naval Petroleum and Oil Shale Reserves started evaluations of oil shale's suitability for military fuels, such as [[jet fuel]]s, marine fuels and a [[heavy fuel oil]]. Shale-oil based JP-4 jet fuel was produced until the early 1990s, when it was replaced with kerosene-based JP-8.<ref name=andrews9/> Seventeen companies led by [[Standard Oil of Ohio]] formed the Paraho Development Corporation to develop the [[Paraho process]]. Production started in 1974 but was closed in 1978.<ref name=assessment110/> In 1974 the [[United States Department of the Interior]] announced an oil shale leasing program in the oil shale regions of [[Colorado]] and [[Utah]]. In 1980 the [[Synthetic Fuels Corporation]] was established which operated until 1985.<ref name=fossilenergyA2/>
In 1972, the first modified ''in situ'' oil shale experiment in the United States was conducted by [[Occidental Petroleum]] at Logan Wash, Colorado.<ref name=fossilenergyA2>[[#fossilenergy|Bunger ''et al.'' (2004)]], pp. A2–A3</ref> [[Rio Blanco Oil Shale Company]], a partnership between [[Gulf Oil]] and [[Standard Oil of Indiana]], originally considered using [[Lurgi–Ruhrgas process|Lurgi–Ruhrgas above-ground retort]] but in 1977 switch also to the modified ''in-situ'' process.<ref name="epa-c-1"/><ref name="assessment124">[[#assessment|OTA (1980)]], p. 124</ref> In 1985 the company ceased its operations.<ref name=knutson86> {{Cite journal | last = Knutson | first = Carroll F. | journal = AAPG Bulletin | title= Developments in Oil Shale in 1985 | year = 1986 | volume = 70 | publisher = [[American Association of Petroleum Geologists]] | doi = 10.1306/94886C86-1704-11D7-8645000102C1865D}} </ref> The White River Shale Corporation, a partnership of [[Sun Oil]], Phillips and [[Sohio]], existed between 1974 and 1986 for developing the tract in the [[Uintah Basin]] on the [[White River (Green River)|White River]] area.<ref name=sage> {{Cite conference | publisher = [[Colorado School of Mines]] | conference = 27th Oil Shale Symposium | title = OSEC's Utah oil shale project | first = Gary | last = Aho | year = 2007 | location = [[Golden, Colorado]] | url = http://www.ceri-mines.org/documents/27symposium/abstracts/ab03-4aho.pdf | format = PDF | accessdate = 2014-09-07}} </ref><ref name="epa-c-3">[[#epa|EPA (1979)]], pp. C-3</ref>
In 1977, [[Superior Oil Company]] cancelled its Meeker shale oil plant project. Year later [[Ashland Inc.|Ashland]], [[Cleveland Cliffs]] and Sohio exited the [[Colony Shale Oil Project]] near [[Parachute, Colorado]]. Also, Shell exited the Colony project but continued with ''in-situ'' test.<ref name=fossilenergyA2/> The United States oil shale industry collapsed when [[1980s oil glut|oil prices fell in the early 1980s]]. On 2 May 1982, known as "Black Sunday", [[ExxonMobil|Exxon]] cancelled the Colony project due to low oil-prices and increased expenses, laying off more than 2,000 workers.<ref name=rocktalk> {{Cite journal | title = Oil shale—enormous potential but...? | publisher = Division of Minerals and Geology of Colorado Geological Survey | journal= RockTalk | date=April 2004 | volume=7 | issue=2 | url = http://geosurvey.state.co.us/pubs/rocktalk/rtv7n2.pdf | format=PDF | accessdate = 2007-07-28 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070713182214/http://geosurvey.state.co.us/pubs/rocktalk/rtv7n2.pdf | archivedate =2007-07-13}} </ref><ref name=chronicle> {{cite news | last = Collier | first = Robert | title = Coaxing oil from huge U.S. shale deposits | publisher = San Francisco Chronicle | date = 2006-09-04 | url = http://www.sfgate.com/news/article/Coaxing-oil-from-huge-U-S-shale-deposits-2489359.php | accessdate = 2008-05-14}} </ref> In 1986, President [[Ronald Reagan]] signed into law the [[Consolidated Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1985]] which among other things abolished the United States' [[Synthetic Liquid Fuels Program]].<ref name=andrews11>[[#andrews|Andrews (2006)]], p. 11</ref> The last oil shale retort in the United States, operated by [[Unocal Corporation]], was closed in 1991.<ref name=fossilenergyA2/>
Because of the success of oil shale-based power generation, Estonian oil shale mining peaked in 1980 at 31.35 million tonnes and oil-shale-based power generation peaked at the same year at 18.9 TWh.<ref name="wec 108"/><ref name=veiderma> {{Cite journal | last = Veiderma| first = M. | title = Estonian oil shale—resources and usage | url = http://www.eap.ee/public/oilshale/3_veiderma_3003_3s.pdf | journal = Oil Shale. A Scientific-Technical Journal | publisher = Estonian Academy Publishers | volume = 20 | issue = 3 Special | pages = 295–303 | year = 2003 | issn = 0208-189X | accessdate=2014-04-06 }}</ref><ref name="eu 45">[[#eu|Francu ''et al''. (2007)]], p. 45</ref> The largest oil shale mine in the world – the Estonia Mine – was opened in 1972.<ref name=ep> {{Cite news |title=Minister of Social Affairs Jaak Aab acquainted himself with the working conditions of the miners |publisher=[[Eesti Põlevkivi]] |date=2006-01-25 |url=http://www.ep.ee/?id=20508 |accessdate=2008-10-25 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070814033514/http://www.ep.ee/?id=20508 |archivedate=2007-08-14 }} </ref> In 1980 the [[Narva Oil Plant]] was commissioned.<ref name="ots 15"/><ref name=golubev> {{Cite journal | last=Golubev | first=Nikolai | title=Solid heat carrier technology for oil shale retorting | journal=Oil Shale. A Scientific-Technical Journal | publisher=Estonian Academy Publishers | volume=20 | issue=3 Special | pages=324–332 | year=2003 | url=http://www.kirj.ee/public/oilshale/6_golubev_2003_3s.pdf | format=PDF | issn=0208-189X | accessdate=2008-12-14}} </ref><ref name=jjmie> {{Cite journal |last1=Jaber |first1=Jamel O. |last2=Sladek |first2=Thomas A. |last3=Mernitz |first3=Scott |last4=Tarawneh |first4=T. M. |title=Future Policies and Strategies for Oil Shale Development in Jordan |year=2008 |volume=2 |issue=1 |pages=31–44 |journal=Jordan Journal of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering |url=http://jjmie.hu.edu.jo/files/V2/004-v2-1.pdf |format=PDF |issn=1995-6665 |accessdate=2008-12-06 }}</ref> The industry declined during the two decades that followed this peak. Demand for locally produced electrical power was reduced by construction of nuclear power stations in the Soviet Union, particularly [[Leningrad Nuclear Power Station]].<ref name="wec 108"/>
In Israel, a 0.1 MW pilot oil shale-fired power plant was tested in 1982–1986. A 12.5 MW [[fluidised-bed]] [[Mishor Rotem Power Station|demonstration plant in Mishor Rotem]] became operational in 1989.<ref name="wec112">[[#wec|Dyni (2010)]], p. 112</ref> In [[Romania]], a [[Crivina Power Station|990 MW oil shale-fired power plant at Crivina]] operated in 1983–1988; however, it was decommissioned due to inefficiency and technical problems.<ref name=pace/><ref name=caon300309> {{cite news |url= http://www.caon.ro/mult-zgomot-pentru-nimic/news-20090330-04474486 |title=Mult zgomot pentru nimic |trans-title= Much ado about nothing |date=2009-03-30 |work=Caras Online |first= Nina | last = Curiţa |language=Romanian |accessdate=2010-09-17}} </ref> In Brazil a 2,400 tons per day semi-works retort (the Irati Profile Plant) was brought on line in 1972, and began limited commercial operation in 1980. A pilot plant that used [[Petrosix]] technology started in 1982. It was followed by a demonstration plant in 1984. A commercial retort was brought into service in December 1991.<ref name=fossilenergy13>[[#fossilenergy|Bunger ''et al.'' (2004)]], p. 13</ref><ref name=qian> {{Cite conference |last = Qian |first = Jialin |author2 = Wang Jianqiu |title = World oil shale retorting technologies |publisher = Jordanian Natural Resources Authority |conference = International Oil Shale Conference |date = 2006-11-07 |location = [[Amman]], [[Jordan]] |url = http://www.sdnp.jo/International_Oil_Conference/rtos-A118.pdf |format = PDF |accessdate = 2007-06-29 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20080527234146/http://www.sdnp.jo/International_Oil_Conference/rtos-A118.pdf |archive-date = 2008-05-27 |dead-url = yes |df = }} </ref>
==Latest developments== The global oil shale industry started to grow slightly in the mid-1990s although most of the industries were ceased in Russia.<ref name="wec117">[[#wec|Dyni (2010)]], p. 117</ref> Oil-shale-fired power stations in Slantsy and Syzran were converted to use natural gas and fuel oil. Also, shale-oil producer ''[[Zavod Slantsy]]'' ceased oil-shale processing.<ref name=lapidus/><ref name="wec117"/><ref name=lapidus2> {{cite web | work = EnergyFuture.ru | url = http://energyfuture.ru/eto-prodolzhenie-stati-goryuchie-slancy-i-slancy-voobshhe-obzornaya-statya/2 | script-title=ru:Горючие сланцы и сланцы вообще: обзорная статья - Часть 2 |trans-title=Oil shale and shales in general: Review article (part 2) | last1 = Lapidus | first1 = A. L. | last2 = Strizhakova | first2 = Yu. A. | date = 2009-03-13 | accessdate = 2014-08-31 | language = Russian}} </ref> Only Syzran processing plant continued using oil shale for production of [[ammonium bituminosulfonate]].<ref name=lapidus/>
Existing shale oil extraction plants in Fushun and Moaming, China, were closed in the beginning of 1990s. However, the new shale oil plants in Fushun consist of 220 retorts and the annual capacity has increased up to 350,000 tonnes of shale oil.<ref name=li/> Several other projects have been developed in various locations.<ref name=qian2/> In 2005, China became the largest shale oil producer in the world with an increased number of companies involved in the shale oil extraction.<ref name=li> {{Cite journal | last = Li | first = Shuyuan | title = The developments of Chinese oil shale activities | journal = [[Oil Shale (journal)|Oil Shale. A Scientific-Technical Journal]] | publisher = Estonian Academy Publishers | volume = 29 | issue = 2 | pages = 101–102 | year = 2012 | url = http://www.kirj.ee/public/oilshale_pdf/2012/issue_2/Oil-2012-2-101-102.pdf | format = PDF | issn = 0208-189X | accessdate = 2012-05-31 | doi=10.3176/oil.2012.2.01}} </ref>
After decrease in the beginning of 1990s Estonian oil shale production has continuously increased since 1995. Several new processing plants using modified [[Galoter]] technology have been built.<ref name="wec110"/> In 2006, 90 years after major mining had begun, one billion tonnes were mined.<ref name="oilfield"/><ref name="kukersiteOS 3"/> Construction of the new 300 MW oil shale-fired power plant began in 2012.<ref name=bns040512> {{Cite news |title = Eesti Energia Lays Cornerstone to New Oil Shale Power Plant in Auvere |agency = [[Baltic News Service|BNS]] |date = 2012-05-04 |url = http://www.vm.ee/?q=en/node/14427 |accessdate = 2014-04-12 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20140413132656/http://www.vm.ee/?q=en%2Fnode%2F14427 |archive-date = 2014-04-13 |dead-url = yes |df = }} </ref>
In Australia, the [[Alberta Taciuk technology]] was used for a [[Stuart Oil Shale Project|demonstration-scale processing plant at the Stuart Deposit]] near [[Gladstone, Queensland]], which produced between 2000 and 2004 over {{convert|1.5|Moilbbl}} of shale oil.<ref name=aimr> {{Cite web | publisher= [[Geoscience Australia]] | url= http://www.australianminesatlas.gov.au/aimr/commodity/shale_oil.html#production | title = Shale oil. AIMR Report 2011 | first = Leesa | last = Carson | accessdate=2012-11-04}} </ref> In 2008–2009, the facility was dismantled and a new demonstration plant based on the [[Paraho II process]] was opened in September 2011.<ref name=aimr/><ref name=ogj140808> {{Cite journal |url=http://www.ogj.com/articles/2008/08/queensland-oil-shale-project-still-in-the-wings.html |title= Queensland oil shale project still in the wings |first = Rick | last= Wilkinson |publisher= [[PennWell Corporation]] |journal= [[Oil & Gas Journal]] |volume= 106 |date=2008-08-14 |accessdate=2008-08-15}} </ref>
In the United States, an oil shale development program was initiated in 2003.<ref name=blm> {{cite web |publisher = [[Bureau of Land Management|BLM]] |url = http://www.blm.gov/wo/st/en/info/newsroom/2005/september/NR_050920.html |title = Nominations for Oil Shale Research Leases Demonstrate Significant Interest in Advancing Energy Technology. Press release |date = 2005-09-20 |accessdate = 2007-07-10 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080916051633/http://www.blm.gov/wo/st/en/info/newsroom/2005/september/NR_050920.html |archivedate = 2008-09-16 |df = }} </ref> The [[Energy Policy Act of 2005]] introduced a commercial leasing program for oil shale and tar sands resources on public lands within the states of Colorado, Utah, and Wyoming.<ref name=anl> {{cite web | publisher= Oil Shale and Tar Sands Leasing Programmatic EIS Information Center | url= http://ostseis.anl.gov/eis/what/index.cfm | title = What's in the Oil Shale and Tar Sands Leasing Programmatic EIS | accessdate=2007-07-10}} </ref> In 2007, leases were awarded to [[Chevron Shale Oil]], EGL Resources (now [[American Shale Oil]]), Oil Shale Exploration Company (now [[Enefit American Oil]]) and [[Shell Frontier Oil & Gas]], and in 2010 to ExxonMobil, Natural Soda and AuraSource.<ref name=lease>{{Cite report | last1=Crawford | first1=Peter M. | last2=Dean | first2= Christopher | last3=Stone | first3=Jeffrey | last4 = Killen | first4 = James C. | title = Assessment of Plans and Progress on US Bureau of Land Management. Oil Shale RD&D Leases in the United States | publisher = [[Bureau of Land Management|BLM]] | date = 2012-04-29 | url= http://energy.gov/sites/prod/files/2013/04/f0/BLM_Final.pdf | format=PDF | ref=lease}}</ref> Several other companies like Red Leaf Resources and TomCo Energy operates on the private leases.<ref name=upstream230811> {{cite news |url= http://www.upstreamonline.com/live/article274008.ece |title=TomCo on Utah shale trail |first = Steve | last = Marshall |newspaper = [[Upstream (newspaper)|Upstream Online]] | publisher = [[NHST Media Group]] |date=2011-08-23 |accessdate=2011-08-23 |id = {{subscription required}}}} </ref> However, Chevron closed its [[Chevron CRUSH]] project in 2012 and Shell closed its [[Mahogany Research Project]] in 2013.<ref name=bizjournals280212> {{Cite news |newspaper = [[Denver Business Journal]] |title= Chevron leaving Western Slope oil shale project |date=2012-02-28 |url= http://www.bizjournals.com/denver/news/2012/02/28/chevron-leaving-western-slope-project.html |accessdate=2012-03-12}} </ref><ref name=ci290212> {{Cite news |newspaper = [[The Colorado Independent]] |title= Chevron giving up oil shale research in western Colorado to pursue other projects |first = Troy | last = Hooper |date=2012-02-29 |url= http://www.coloradoindependent.com/114365/chevron-giving-up-oil-shale-research-in-western-colorado-to-pursue-other-projects |accessdate=2014-03-31}} </ref><ref name=dp250913> {{Cite news |newspaper = [[The Denver Post]] |title= Shell abandons Western Slope oil-shale project |first = Mark | last = Jaffe |date=2013-09-25 |url= http://www.denverpost.com/breakingnews/ci_24167353/shell-abandons-western-slope-oil-shale-project |accessdate=2014-09-07}} </ref>
Since 2006 the government of Jordan has signed a number of memorandum of understanding with foreign companies for shale oil production, including with Petrobras, and has signed concession agreements with Shell, [[Eesti Energia]], Karak International Oil and Saudi Arabian International Corporation for Oil Shale Investment.<ref name=jordantimes250209> {{Cite news | title = Kingdom set to sign oil shale deal with Shell | first = Hani |last = Hazaimeh | newspaper = [[The Jordan Times]] | date = 2009-02-25 | url= http://www.jordantimes.com/index.php?news=14593 | accessdate = 2009-04-19}} </ref><ref name=bc120510> {{Cite news | title = Eesti Energia signs oil shale concession agreement with Jordan | first = Juhan |last = Tere | newspaper = The Baltic Course | date = 2010-05-12 | url= http://www.baltic-course.com/eng/energy/?doc=26802 | accessdate = 2013-01-05}} </ref><ref name=jordantimes051011> {{Cite news | title = Oil shale extraction agreement with UK firm approved | newspaper = [[The Jordan Times]] | date = 2011-10-05 | url= http://www.jordantimes.com/?news=41980 | accessdate = 2011-10-25}} </ref><ref name=jordantimes030313> {{Cite news |title = Cabinet approves deals for shale oil distillation, oil exploration |agency = [[Jordan News Agency|Petra]] |newspaper = [[The Jordan Times]] |date = 2013-03-03 |url = http://jordantimes.com/cabinet-approves-deals-for-shale-oil-distillation-oil-exploration |accessdate = 2013-03-06 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130306042854/http://jordantimes.com/cabinet-approves-deals-for-shale-oil-distillation-oil-exploration |archivedate = 2013-03-06 |df = }} </ref> In 2008, the Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources of Jordan, the National Electricity Power Company of Jordan, and Eesti Energia signed an agreement to build the 460 MW oil shale-fired [[Attarat Power Plant]].<ref name=jordantimes> {{Cite news | title = Jordan's first oil shale power plant expected in 7 years | newspaper = [[The Jordan Times]] | date = 2008-05-01 | url= http://www.jordantimes.com/index.php?news=7553 | accessdate =2008-10-25}} </ref><ref name=bbn> {{Cite news | title = Eesti Energia signed an exclusive contract with Jordan | first = Sandra | last = Taimre | publisher = Baltic Business News | date = 2008-04-30 | url= http://bbn.ee/Default2.aspx?ArticleID=0d384ae3-a6b1-4d8a-be73-a743fa935797 | accessdate =2008-10-25}} </ref>
In 2005 Morocco adopted a new strategy and legal framework for oil shale activities.<ref name=bencherifa> {{Cite conference | last1 = Bencherifa | first1 = Mohammed | last2 = Alami | first2 = A. Chakor | last3 = Epifanio | first3 = Demarco | last4 = Mendonça | first4 = Augusto | last5 = Allix | first5 = Pierre | last6 = Sabbag | first6 = Jean-Nicolas | title = Timahdit Oil Shale Deposit Evaluation - Morocco | conference = 28th Oil Shale Symposium | location = [[Golden, Colorado]] | url= http://www.ceri-mines.org/documents/28thsymposium/presentations08/PRES_13-3_Bencherifa_Mohammed.pdf | format = PDF | date = 2008-10-15 | accessdate =2011-10-27}} </ref> Since then different agreements have been signed with a number of companies, including Petrobras, [[Total S.A.]] and [[San Leon Energy]].<ref name="wec116"/> In April 2010, the 4th Workshop on Regional Cooperation for Clean Utilization of Oil Shale was held in Egypt and later the same month an Oil Shale Cooperation Center was established in [[Amman]] by Egypt, Jordan, Morocco, Syria and Turkey.<ref name="wec116"/> In 2011, Israel closed the [[Mishor Rotem Power Station]].<ref name=globes220311> {{Cite news | last1 = Azulai | first1 =Yuval | title = We are not drying up the Dead Sea | newspaper= [[Globes]] | date = 2011-03-22 | url = http://www.globes.co.il/en/article-1000632377 | accessdate =2012-03-15}} </ref>
In 2013, [[Uzbekistan]]i national oil company [[Uzbekneftegaz]] started construction of the shale oil extraction plant on the [[Sangruntau oil shale deposit]].<ref name=azer170513> {{Cite news | last1 = Jafarova | first1 = Aynur | title = Oil-shale processing plant to be commissioned in Uzbekistan by 2016 | newspaper= Azernews | date = 2013-05-17 | url = http://www.azernews.az/oil_and_gas/54032.html | accessdate =2014-09-07}} </ref>

For multiple names in different languages, use {{lang|[code]|[name]}}. --> | former_name = | type = | industry = Technology | founded = 2006 | founder = Aytekin Tank<ref>{{Cite web | url = https://www.entrepreneur.com/article/284682 | title = This Engineer-Turned-Entrepreneur Spends Half His Workday Hiring the Right People | work = Entrepreneur | date = 4 November 2016}}</ref> | hq_location = [[San Francisco]] | hq_location_city = | hq_location_country = | area_served = <!-- or: | areas_served = --> | key_people = | products = | brands = | services = | owner = <!-- or: | owners = --> | ratio = <!-- for BANKS ONLY --> | rating = <!-- for BANKS ONLY --> | website = {{URL|jotform.com}} }}
'''JotForm''' is a [[San Francisco]]-based online form building company.<ref name=eweek/> JotForm's software creates forms with a [[drag and drop]] creation tool and an option to [[encryption|encrypt]] user data.<ref name=next/> As of 2015, JotForm had 2 million registered users and 7,000 form templates.<ref name=dj/> The forms can be integrated on external sites including [[MailChimp]], [[PayPal]], [[Stripe (company)|Stripe]], and [[Salesforce.com|Salesforce]].<ref name=biz/>
==History== JotForm was founded in 2006 by Aytekin Tank.<ref name=dj/><ref name=wsj/><ref name=hotel/> In 2011, JotForm released Wishbox, a feedback tool that annotates screenshots.<ref name=nw/><ref name=tc/> By 2012, JotForm had over 700,000 users and published over 2 million user forms.<ref name=nextweb/> JotForm released an [[Adobe Systems|Adobe]] Document Cloud eSign Widget in June 2015 for embedded esigning into forms.<ref name=sbt/><ref name=tech/>
In April 2016, JotForm announced that its software was available on [[Weebly]].<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.martechadvisor.com/news/interactive-content/weebly-users-gain-access-to-easytouse-formcreator-jotform/ | title = Weebly Users Gain Access to Easy-to-use Form-Creator JotForm | publisher = Martech Advisor | date = 1 April 2016 | author = Roy, Rohit}}</ref> In December 2016, the company partnered with [[IFTTT]] to integrate an "Applet" to create forms in other applications.<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/jotform-and-ifttts-new-integration-connects-form-responses-to-hundreds-of-new-apps-300373092.html | title = JotForm and IFTTT's New Integration Connects Form Responses to Hundreds of New Apps | work = PR Newswire | date = 6 December 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web | url = http://tech.co/little-ifttt-applets-company-try-2016-12 | title = 6 Little-Known IFTTT Applets Your Company Should Try | work = Tech.co | date = 7 December 2016}}</ref> ''Tech Times'' recognized JotForm online form integration on [[Slack (software)|Slack]] as one of the "Best Productivity Apps" of 2016.<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://www.techtimes.com/articles/190205/20161226/best-productivity-apps-to-help-you-achieve-your-goals-organize-your-work-and-collaborate-with-your-colleagues.htm | title = Best Productivity Apps To Help You Achieve Your Goals, Organize Your Work, And Collaborate With Your Colleagues | work = Tech Times | date = 26 December 2016}}</ref>
==Controversy== In February 2012, the [[United States Secret Service]] shut down the JotForm site as part of an undisclosed investigation of user-created forms. After two days, the site was back up.<ref name=eweek/><ref name=td/><ref name=wired/>

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox magazine | title = L’Aérophile | image_file = L'Aérophile_cover_1898.jpg{{!}}border | image_size = 250px | image_alt = | image_caption = <center>''L'Aérophile'' cover from 1898</center> | editor = [[Georges Besançon]], [[Wilfrid de Fonvielle]], Emmanuel Aimé | editor_title = Editors | previous_editor = | staff_writer = | frequency = Monthly; weekly | circulation = | category = | company = | publisher = [[Aéro-Club de France]], Blondel la Rougery | firstdate = 1893 | finaldate = 1947 | finalnumber = | country = France | based = Paris | language = French | website = | issn = | lccn = 31033298 }}
'''''L’Aérophile''''' was a French aviation [[magazine]] published from 1893 to 1947.<ref>[[Charles Dollfus|Dollfus, Charles]]. 1975. ''Locomotion Aérienne & Terrestre: Précurseurs et Pionniers''. Paris. entry 179. (no page number)</ref> It has been described as "the leading aeronautical journal of the world" around 1910.<ref>[[Charles Harvard Gibbs-Smith|Gibbs-Smith, Charles]]. 1968. ''Clément Ader: His Flight-Claims and his Place in History.'' London: Her Majesty’s Stationery Office. p. 75</ref>
== History and contents == ''L’Aérophile'' was founded and run for many years by [[Georges Besançon]]. In 1898 it became the official journal of the [[Aéro-Club de France|Aéro Club of France]].<ref>[http://www.aeroclub.com/santos_dumont_14bis_14bis_2.htm Official Aéro Club of France site history] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707092457/http://www.aeroclub.com/santos_dumont_14bis_14bis_2.htm |date=7 July 2011 }}</ref>
Important developments in early aviation were documented in its pages:
* [[Octave Chanute]]'s April 1903 speech to the Aéro-Club describing the excitement of the [[gliding]] experiments done by his group in 1896/7 and of the [[Wright brothers]] <ref>Short, Simine. 2011. ''Locomotive to Aeromotive. Octave Chanute and the Transportation Revolution''. pp. 255-8.</ref> was printed in April, 1903.<ref>Crouch, Tom D. 1981, 2002. ''A Dream of Wings: Americans and the Airplane, 1875-1905''. p. 20.</ref> Also [[Ferdinand Ferber]]'s 1902 glider, the first in Europe modeled on those of the Wright brothers, was illustrated in the February 1903 issue.<ref>[[Charles Harvard Gibbs-Smith|Gibbs-Smith, Charles]]. 1970 and 2000. ''Aviation: An historical survey from its origins to the end of the Second World War''. Science Museum. p. 128.</ref> * The journal published illustrations of [[ailerons]] on [[Robert Esnault-Pelterie]]’s glider in June 1905, and the ailerons were widely copied afterward.<ref>[[Robert Esnault-Pelterie|Esnault-Pelterie, Robert]]. [https://archive.org/stream/larophile13besa#page/132/mode/2up "Expériences d'aviation, exécutées en 1904, en vérification de celles des frères Wright."] ''L'Aérophile'', June 1905, pp. 132-138.</ref><ref>[[Charles Harvard Gibbs-Smith|Gibbs-Smith, Charles]]. 1970 and 2000. ''Aviation: An historical survey from its origins to the end of the Second World War''. Science Museum. p. 138.</ref> * In December 1905 and January 1906 journal articles confirmed that the Wright brothers had (as they claimed) flown a controlled, powered airplane, at a time when many readers did not believe this.<ref>[https://archive.org/stream/larophile13besa#page/264/mode/2up "Les frères Wright et leur aéroplane à moteur." ''L'Aérophile'' 13:12 (December 1905), pp. 265-272.]</ref><ref>[[Richard P. Hallion|Hallion, Richard P.]] 2003. ''Taking Flight: inventing the Aerial Age from Antiquity through the First World War''. Oxford University Press. pp. 218-219.</ref> * The journal covered at length [[Alberto Santos-Dumont]]’s flights of 1906, which were the first airplane flights in Europe.<ref>[http://www.aeroclub.com/santos_dumont_14bis_14bis_2.htm Official Aéro Club of France site history page on Santos-Dumont] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707092457/http://www.aeroclub.com/santos_dumont_14bis_14bis_2.htm |date=7 July 2011 }}</ref> * Editor Georges Besançon wrote that Wilbur Wright’s 1908 flights in France had erased doubts about the Wright brothers' previous experiments.<ref>''L'Aérophile'', 15 August 1908, quoted in Crouch, Tom D. 2003, ''Wings: A history of aviation from kites to the space age'', p. 105.</ref> * ''L'Aérophile'' published [[René Lorin]]’s article of 1 September 1908 in which he first proposed the [[ramjet]].<ref>[[Charles Harvard Gibbs-Smith|Gibbs-Smith, Charles]]. 1970 and 2000. ''Aviation: An historical survey from its origins to the end of the Second World War''. Science Museum. pp. 163-164.</ref>
Historian [[Charles Gibbs-Smith]] criticised ''L’Aérophile'' for not publishing the official report on the tests of [[Clément Ader]]’s 1897 ''Avion III'' when this report was finally made public in 1910, and thus failing to oppose the claim that Ader's machine had made a controlled flight in 1897.<ref>[[Charles Harvard Gibbs-Smith|Gibbs-Smith, Charles]]. 1968. ''Clement Ader: His Flight-Claims and his Place in History.'' London: Her Majesty’s Stationery Office. p. 75</ref>
''L'Aérophile'' was a monthly publication in its first years, then started to come out twice a month in 1910.
== Affiliations== From 1893-4, ''L'Aérophile'' was associated with the Union aérophile de France.<ref>[https://archive.org/details/larophile18besa archive.org index page for ''L'Aérophile'']</ref> Starting at the end of 1898 it was the official journal of the [[Aero Club of France]]. In later years it was also an official publication of the alumni association (Association des anciens élèves) of the French national aeronautical college (École nationale supérieure de l'aéronautique).
==Bibliography and archives == Some early issues have been scanned and are available at [https://archive.org/search.php?query=creator:%28A%20Club%20de%20France%29 archive.org] thanks to the Smithsonian Institution Libraries. Other issues are online at [https://books.google.com/books?id=fvrNAAAAMAAJ&q=editions:gM_NAAAAMAAJ&dq=editions:gM_NAAAAMAAJ&hl=en&ei=iXqvTLb0BYaglAeAguHkDw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CDsQ6AEwBTgU google books].
Some portion of the ''L'Aérophile'' archives are kept by the US Library of Congress.<ref>[https://www.loc.gov/rr/scitech/trs/trslaerophile.html ''L'Aérophile'' Collection Overview, Science References Services of the Library of Congress]</ref><ref>[http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.gdc/eadgdc.gc006001 Overview of finding aid for ''L'Aérophile'' collection at the Library of Congress]</ref><ref>[http://lcweb2.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/h?faid/faid:@field%28DOCID+gc006001%29 Detailed finding aid for ''L'Aérophile'' collection at the Library of Congress]</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External link==
* {{cite web|language=fr|url=https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/cb344143803/date|title=Gallica archives of L'Aérophile issues}}
