revision.text:
{{About||the use of satellites for terrestrial archaeology|Remote sensing (archaeology)|the search for extraterrestrial intelligence|SETI}}
[[File:MarsLander2.JPG|thumb|[[NASA]]'s Phoenix Mars Lander]] In [[archaeology]], '''space archaeology''' is the research-based study of various human-made items found in space, their interpretation as clues to the adventures mankind has experienced in space, and their preservation as cultural heritage.<ref name=Archaeology>{{cite journal|last=Capelotti|first=P.J.|title=Space: The Final [Archaeological] Frontier|journal=Archaeology|date=November–December 2004|volume=57| issue = 6|url=http://www.archaeology.org/0411/etc/space.html|accessdate=3 June 2012|publisher=Archaeological Institute of America}}</ref>
It includes launch complexes on Earth, orbital debris, satellites, and objects and structures on other celestial bodies such as Mars. It also includes the applied field of cultural resource which evaluates the significance of space sites and objects in terms of national and international preservation laws. Cultural resource looks at what, how and why these artifacts of our recent history should be preserved for future generations.
==Cultural heritage== {{See also|Cultural resources management}} Space tourism could affect archaeological artifacts, for example, on the Moon.<ref name=Fewer>{{cite journal |author=Greg Fewer |year=2007 |journal=Journal of the British Interplanetary Society |volume=60 |pages=3–8 |url=http://eprints.wit.ie/30/ |title=Conserving space heritage: The case of Tranquility Base|bibcode=2007JBIS...60....3F }} Conference paper from Archaeology for Space Symposium</ref><ref name=Ormrod>{{cite book |title=Cosmic Society: Towards a Sociology of the Universe |url=https://books.google.com/?id=gx08Kj0ZNowC&pg=PP11 |author1=Peter Dickens |author2=James S. Ormrod |isbn=0-415-37432-4 |year=2007 |publisher=Routledge}}</ref><ref name=LLMS>The [http://www.l2ms.com/about.html Lunar Land Management System] began in January 2007 and is currently based in the Mojave Desert of California at the Mojave Spaceport. The Mojave Spaceport is "an innovator in the privatization of space travel and is quickly becoming a gateway to the stars."</ref> The notion that cultural heritage is at stake and requires action to prevent deterioration or destruction is gaining ground.<ref name=Oleary2>{{cite journal |title=The cultural heritage of space, the Moon and other celestial bodies |author=Beth Laura O'Leary |url=http://antiquity.ac.uk/Projgall/oleary/ |journal=Antiquity |volume=80 |year=2006}}</ref><ref name=Spennemann2>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.spacepol.2004.08.005 |title=The ethics of treading on Neil Armstrong's footprints |author=Dirk HR Spennemann |year=2004 |journal=Space Policy |volume=20 |issue=4 |pages=279–290}}</ref><ref name=Gorman2>{{cite journal |author=Alice Gorman|authorlink=Alice Gorman |title=The cultural landscape of interplanetary space |journal=Journal of Social Archaeology |volume=5 |pages=85–107 |year=2005 |doi=10.1177/1469605305050148 |url=http://jsa.sagepub.com/cgi/content/abstract/5/1/85 |issue=1}}</ref> Perhaps artifacts (say, antiquated space stations) could be preserved in "museum orbit".<ref name=Gorman5>[https://flinders.academia.edu/AliceGorman/attachment/98986/full/Leaving-the-cradle-of-Earth---the-heritage-of-Low-Earth-Orbit--1957-1963 Gorman (2007)]</ref> Many such artifacts have been lost because they were not recognized and assessed. Experts assert that continuity and connection to the past are vital elements of survival in the modern world.<ref name=Gorman3>{{cite journal |title=The Archaeology of Orbital Space |url=http://ehlt.flinders.edu.au/archaeology/department/publications/Gorman/The%20Archaeology%20of%20Orbital%20Space.pdf |author=Alice C Gorman |journal=Australian Space Science Conference |year=2005 |pages=338–357 }}</ref> A model has been suggested for international cooperation based upon Antarctica.<ref name=Spennemann>{{cite journal |title=Out of this World: Issues of Managing Tourism and Humanity's Heritage on the Moon |journal=Intl J of Heritage Studies |volume=12 |issue=4 |year=2006 |pages=356–371 |author=D Spennemann |url=http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/routledg/rjhs/2006/00000012/00000004/art00005 |doi=10.1080/13527250600726911}}</ref> Implications for cooperation interest anthropologists as well.<ref name=MacDonald>{{cite journal |author=Fraser MacDonald |title=Anti-''Astropolitik'' – outer space and the orbit of geography |journal=Progress in Human Geography |volume=31 |pages=592–615 |year=2007 |url=http://phg.sagepub.com/cgi/content/abstract/31/5/592 |doi=10.1177/0309132507081492 |issue=5}}</ref>
An unexpected ramification of this work is the development of techniques for detecting signs of life or technology on other planets, or extraterrestrial visitation on Earth.<ref name=Campbell>{{cite book |author=John B Campbell |chapter=Archaeology and direct imaging of exoplanets |year=2006 |pages=247''ff'' |isbn=0-521-85607-8 |editor1=C. Aime |editor2=F. Vakili |url=http://eprints.jcu.edu.au/1027/1/S1743921306009392a.pdf |title=Proceedings of the International Astronomical Union |publisher=Cambridge University Press |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090326065433/http://eprints.jcu.edu.au/1027/1/S1743921306009392a.pdf |archivedate=2009-03-26 |df= }}</ref><ref name=Campbell2>{{cite book |author=Campbell, J.B. |chapter=The potential for archaeology within and beyond the habitable zones of the Milky Way |editor= Norris, R. |editor2=Stootman, F.|title=Bioastronomy 2002: Life among the Stars. International Astronomical Union Symposium 213 |bibcode=2004IAUS..213..505C |isbn=1-58381-171-0 |publisher= Astronomical Society of the Pacific |year=2004}}</ref><ref name=G_Fewer>Greg Fewer, ''[http://www.spacearchaeology.org/wiki/index.php?title=Searching_for_extraterrestrial_intelligence Searching for extraterrestrial intelligence'']. A pdf file [http://www.nidsci.org/pdf/fewer.pdf here] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927065558/http://www.nidsci.org/pdf/fewer.pdf |date=2007-09-27 }}.</ref> One facet of this work is the use of satellites for identifying structures of archeological significance.<ref name=Carlotto >{{cite journal |url=http://spsr.utsi.edu/articles/markjbis2007.pdf |title=Detecting Patterns of a Technological Intelligence in Remotely Sensed Imagery |author= MJ Carlotto |journal=Journal of the British Interplanetary Society|volume=60 |pages=28–39 |year=2007|bibcode=2007JBIS...60...28C }}</ref><ref name=Wiseman>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/?id=DqL9yELrcZMC&pg=PA1 |title=Remote Sensing in Archaeology |author1=James Wiseman |author2=Farouk El-Baz |lastauthoramp=yes |page=1 |isbn=0-387-44615-X |publisher=Springer |year=2007}}</ref><ref name=Conolly>{{cite book |title=Geographical Information Systems in Archaeology |author1=James Conolly |author2=Mark Lake |isbn=0-521-79330-0 |year=2006 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |page=72 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=fMCqf-YSRtsC&pg=PA72 }}</ref><ref name=Fort>{{cite book |author=R. Lassaponara|chapter=VHR satellite images for the knowledge and the enhancement of cultural landscapes |url=https://books.google.com/?id=wRgToVcJuXgC&pg=PA841|title=Heritage, Weathering and Conservation |pages=841''ff'' |publisher=Taylor & Francis Group |isbn=0-415-41272-2 |editors=Fort, Alvarez de Buergo, Gomez-Heras & Vazquez-Calvo |year=2006|display-authors=etal}}</ref>
==Satellites== Satellites are key artifacts in examining human encounters with space over time and the effect we leave through artificial objects. This list includes: * [[Vanguard 1]] - Launched in 1958, the manmade satellite Vanguard 1 and the upper stage of its launch rocket are the oldest still in orbit. Vanguard 1 lost communication in 1964 but had a few different functions, including the obtention of geodetic measurements and the testing of capabilities.<ref>[http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraftDisplay.do?id=1958-002B] NASA. NASA, n.d. Web. 26 Feb. 2015.</ref> * [[Asterix-1]] - With the intention of testing the French Diamant Rocket, Asterix-1 was the first French satellite launched into space. Asterix-1 had a very short lived transmission period of 2 days but remains in orbit and is expected to for centuries.<ref>[http://spacearchaeology.org/] Space Archaeology." Space Archaeology. N.p., n.d. Web. 26 Feb. 2015.</ref> * [[Skynet 1A]] - Providing communication to Middle Eastern forces, Skynet 1A was launched over the Indian Ocean in 1969. No longer in operation, Skynet 1A has an approximate lifetime of more than 1 million years.<ref name="Space Archaeology 2015">Space Archaeology." Space Archaeology. N.p., n.d. Web. 26 Feb. 2015.</ref> * [[Kosmos 2222]] - With the intended function of identifying ballistic missiles launches, Cosmos-2222 was launched in 1992. With an operation life of 4 years, Cosmos and its rocket body remain in orbit today.<ref name="Space Archaeology 2015"/>
Satellites are just one example of several human traces we leave behind in, and out of this world.
==Legal matters== {{Main|Space law}} {{See also|Common heritage of mankind}} The complexities and ambiguities of international legal structures to deal with these sites as cultural resources leave them vulnerable to impacts in the near future by many varieties of space travel. An outline of the legal situation was made by [[Harrison Schmitt]] and [[Neil Armstrong]], both of them astronauts who walked on the moon as part of the [[Apollo program]].<ref name=Armstrong>{{cite book |title=Return to the Moon |author1=Harrison H. Schmitt |author2=Neil Armstrong |url=https://books.google.com/?id=g06vVWEW2mgC&pg=PA280 |pages=280''ff'' |isbn=0-387-24285-6 |publisher=Birkhäuser |year=2006}}</ref> The governing law on the Moon and other celestial bodies is the ''Outer Space Treaty'' of 1967 based upon guidelines from experience in the Antarctic. Another source of ideas is the ''Law of the Sea''. The ''Outer Space Treaty'' contains language stating that space objects remain under the jurisdiction of the originating state, and the civil and criminal laws of that state govern private parties both on the Moon and ''events leading up to such activity''. State parties are to inform the public about the nature and result of their activities.
The later ''Moon Agreement'' of 1979 was signed but not ratified by many spacefaring nations. Schmitt and Armstrong believe this lack of ratification relates to disagreement over wording such as "the Moon and its natural resources are the [[common heritage of mankind]]", which is taken as possibly excluding private activity, and objections to wording concerning the disruption of the existing environment.{{citation needed|date=May 2015}} <!-- For an extensive discussion see Schmitt and Armstrong.<ref name=Armstrong/> For the treaty text see [http://www1.umn.edu/humanrts/peace/docs/treatyouterspace.html UN treaty on outer space of 1967]. -->
A non-profit organization called [[For All Moonkind, Inc.]] is working to establish legal protections for archaeological sites in outer space. The entirely volunteer group includes space lawyers and policymakers from around the world. As a result of their efforts, the [[United Nations Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space]] agreed, in January 2018, to consider the creation of a "universal space heritage sites program.".<ref>{{cite web|last1=UNCOPUOS|title=Draft Declaration|url=http://www.unoosa.org/res/oosadoc/data/documents/2018/aac_105c_12018crp/aac_105c_12018crp_6_0_html/AC105_C1_2018_CRP06E.pdf|website=unoosa.org|publisher=UNOOSA|accessdate=7 February 2018}}</ref> Having created a discussion around preservation in outer space, For All Moonkind is now focused on preparing drafts of implementing regulations and protocols.
==Background and history== During a graduate seminar at New Mexico State University in 1999, Ralph Gibson asked: "Does federal preservation law apply on the moon?" That question led to Gibson's thesis "''Lunar Archaeology: The Application of Federal Historic Preservation Law to the Site where Humans first set foot upon the Moon''", to a grant from the New Mexico Space Grant Consortium, and to creation of the Lunar Legacy Project.<ref>http://spacegrant.nmsu.edu/lunarlegacies/</ref>
A manuscript by scientists at [[NASA]] and [[ESA]] in 2004 raised the possibility of preserving Apollo landing sites for future "astroarcheologists."<ref name="Glavin et al. 2004">{{cite web|title=Glavin et al. (2004) Int. J. Astrobio. 3, 265-271.|url=https://doi.org/10.1017/S1473550404001958#}}.</ref>
In 2006, Dr. O’Leary with New Mexico State Historic Preservation Officer Katherine Slick and the [[New Mexico Museum of Space History]] (NMMSH), documented the [[Apollo 11]] Tranquility Base archaeological site on the Moon.<ref name=Newsletter>[http://lib.nmsu.edu/aboutlib/newsletter/sept02.pdf New Mexico State University Newsletter].</ref> Some legal aspects of this work already have surfaced.<ref name=Oleary>[http://spacegrant.nmsu.edu/lunarlegacies/lunar_archaeology.pdf Applicability of federal historic preservation law]</ref>
Though its mission isn't primarily archaeological, the [[Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter]] has imaged all of the Apollo landing sites as well as rediscovering the location of the first [[Lunokhod 1]] rover, lost since 1971 (note: all of the U. S. flags left on the moon during the Apollo missions were found to still be standing, with the exception of the one left during the Apollo 11 mission, which was blown over during that mission's lift-off from the lunar surface and return to the mission command module in lunar orbit; the degree to which these flags are preserved and intact remains unknown).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://lroc.sese.asu.edu/news/index.php?/archives/620-Question-Answered!.html |title=Question Answered! |last=Robinson |first=Mark |date=27 July 2012 |work=LROC News System |publisher=[[Arizona State University]] |accessdate=28 October 2012}}</ref>
Based on an idea by British amateur astronomer Nick Howes, a team of experts has been assembled to try to locate the [[Lunar Module]] of the [[Apollo 10]] mission nicknamed "Snoopy", which was released during the mission and is currently thought to be in a [[heliocentric orbit]].<ref name=redorbit.com>{{cite web|title=Astronomy Team Looking For Lost ‘Snoopy’ Module From Apollo 10|url=http://www.redorbit.com/news/space/1112391824/astronomy-team-looking-for-lost-snoopy-module-from-apollo-10/|accessdate=3 June 2012}}</ref> The Snoopy mission is encouraged by the 2002 re-sighting of the [[Apollo 12]] third-stage rocket.<ref name=redorbit.com/>
==See also==

O'Leary, et al.: ''Archaeology and Heritage of the Human Movement into Space.'' Springer, Cham 2015, {{ISBN|978-3-319-07865-6}}.

archaeological treasure trove] Leonard David at the Coalition for Space Exploration *[http://spacegrant.nmsu.edu/lunarlegacies/ Lunar legacy project] {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2017}} {{Missing information|the SIR-A and SIR-B missions|date=January 2017}} {{Infobox spaceflight | name = ''Spaceborne Imaging Radar (SIR)'' | image = SIR-C_X-SAR_JPL.jpg | image_caption = SIR-C/X-SAR in the payload bay of space shuttle Endeavour on STS-59, 9 April 1994. | image_alt = | image_size = 300px | mission_type = [[Earth science]] | operator = [[NASA]]{{,}}[[Jet Propulsion Laboratory|JPL]] | COSPAR_ID = | SATCAT = | website = {{url|jpl.nasa.gov/missions/spaceborne-imaging-radar-c-x-band-synthetic-aperture-radar-sir-c-x-sar/}} | mission_duration = Two trips, 11 days each | manufacturer = [[JPL]] | landing_mass = | dimensions = | power = | launch_date = 9 April 1994 and 30 September 1994 | launch_rocket = [[STS-59]] and [[STS-68]] | launch_site = [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station|Cape Canaveral]] | launch_contractor = | last_contact = |interplanetary = | instruments_list = }} [[File:unzen volcano.jpg|thumb|Spaceborne radar image of [[Unzen]]
{{resize|90%|Taken from Space Shuttle, 15 April 1994}}]] The '''Spaceborne Imaging Radar''' ('''SIR''') – full name 'Spaceborne Imaging Radar-C/X-band Synthetic Aperture Radar (SIR-C/X-SAR)', is a [[synthetic aperture radar]] which flew on two separate shuttle missions. Once from the [[Space Shuttle Endeavour]] in April 1994 on ([[STS-59]]) and again in October 1994 on ([[STS-68]]). The radar was run by NASA's [[Space Radar Laboratory]]. SIR utilizes 3 radar frequencies: [[L band]] (24 cm [[wavelength]]), [[C band (IEEE)|C band]] (6 cm) and [[X band]] (3 cm),{{cite web |url=http://photojournal.jpl.nasa.gov/catalog/PIA00504 |title=Catalog Page for PIA00504 |publisher=Photojournal.jpl.nasa.gov |date= |accessdate=5 May 2014}} allowing for study of geology, hydrology, ecology and oceanography. Comparing radar images to data collected by teams of people on the ground as well as aircraft and ships using simultaneous measurements of vegetation, soil moisture, sea state, snow and weather conditions during each flight. The imaging radar was able to take images anytime regardless of clouds cover. The Radar-C system was built and operated by [[National Aeronautics and Space Administration|NASA's]] [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] (JPL). The mission was a joint work of NASA with the [[German Aerospace Center|German]] and [[Italian Space Agency|Italian]] space agencies.{{cite web |title=Spaceborne Imaging Radar |url=http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/fact_sheets/radar.pdf |publisher=NASA/JPL |accessdate=5 May 2014 |format=PDF }}[http://photojournal.jpl.nasa.gov/catalog/PIA01321 NASA JPL, Photo, SIR-C/X-SAR] Each of the week long mission scanned about 50 million square kilometers of the Earth's surface, (19.3 million square miles).[http://trmm.jpl.nasa.gov/SIRCdesc.html NASA JPL, What is SIR-C/X-SAR?] The SIR mission revealed hidden river channels in the [[Sahara Desert]] indicating significant climate change in the past.{{cite press release|url=http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/releases/96/sirnile.html |title=Space radar unearths secrets of the Nile |publisher=Jpl.nasa.gov |date=6 December 1996 |accessdate=5 May 2014}} SIR was also used for volcano research by keeping researchers a safe distance from hazardous and often inaccessible areas. The radar was also used to generate detailed three dimensional mappings of the Earth's surface. Radar also found temples in [[Angkor]],[http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/releases/98/angkor98.html NASA JPL Press Release, February 12, 1998 ][http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?feature=5437 JPL, February 7, 1995, Space Radar Laboratory Images May Help Find Unknown Settlements] and ancient segments of [[China's Great Wall]].[http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?feature=5401 JPL, April 18, 1996, Space Radar Reveals Ancient Segments of China's Great Wall] ==Specification== *Orbital altitude above earth = 225 km (139.8 miles) *The width of the imaged swath on the ground = 15–90 kilometers (9–56 miles) *C-band beamwidth = 0.25 deg. × 5 deg. *L-band beamwidth = 1.1 deg. × 6 deg. *Scan angle range = ±23 deg. from boresight across narrow antenna direction only *Bandwidth = 10, 20 and 40 GHz *Pulse repetition rate = 1395–1736 pulses per second *Total science data = 50 hours per channel, per mission (two missions, total 100 hours) *Total instrument mass = 11,000 kg (2,4250.8 pounds) *DC power consumption = 3000–9000 Watts *L-band data rate = 90 Mbit/s *C-band data rate = 90 Mbit/s *X-band data rate = 45 Mbit/s *L-band wavelength = 0.235 m *C-band Wavelength = 0.058 m *X-band wavelength = 0.031 m == See also == {{Commonscat|SIR-C/X-SAR}} * [[Seasat]] – Seasat Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) in 1978 * [[STS-2]] with SIR-A * [[STS-41-G]] with SIR-B * [[Shuttle Radar Topography Mission]] * [[TerraSAR-X]] * [[Earth Radiation Budget Satellite]] * [[TopSat]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Use American English|date=January 2014}} {{Jet Propulsion Laboratory}} [[Category:Spacecraft instruments]] [[Category:1994 in spaceflight]] [[Category:Satellite meteorology and remote sensing]] [[Category:Space synthetic aperture radar]]

revision.comment: /* External links */Typo fixing, replaced: Guatamala → Guatemala per the banner of the linked web page using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Use British English|date=January 2014}}
'''Threshing''' is a key part of agriculture that involves removing the seeds or [[grain]] from plants (for example rice or wheat) from the plant [[Plant stem|stalk]]. In the case of small farms, threshing is done by beating or crushing the grain by hand or foot, and requires a large amount of hard [[Manual labour|physical labour]]. A simple [[threshing machine|thresher]] with a [[Crank (mechanism)|crank]] can be used to make this work much easier for the farmer. In most cases it takes two people to work these: one person to turn the crank and the other to feed the grain through the machine. These threshers can be built using simple materials and can improve the efficiency of grain threshing. They can also be built with pedals, or be attached to a bicycle, so that the person operating it can simply pedal to reduce the work even more and make threshing faster.
Threshers can be made in a number of ways using simple tools, and can be used in the harvesting of maize/corn, rice, wheat, [[sorghum]], [[pearl millet]], and any other grain or seed that must be separated from a stalk. The attachment of a thresher to a pedal-system can be built with basic materials. Two versions are the pedal-powered thresher which is built as one piece and the attachment to a bicycle for a regular thresher with a crank.<ref name=Mtshali/> Pedal-powered threshers have been suggested or made available to farming communities by governmental or non-governmental organizations. It should be remembered that there are some disadvantages to these threshers and their impact in the specific region should be researched before being suggested.
==Threshers== Thresher are many different designs for threshers and they can be made from wood or metal. The shape of the thresher can vary, but it must include some main parts: *A cylinder with spikes or loops that will pull the grains off the stalks as they are held onto the cylinder, or pushed through.<ref name=Dewangan/> These cylinders can be made from metal, or a progression of wooden boards that form a wheel.<ref name=Dewangan/><ref name=Ebenezer/><ref name=Singh/> Different designs that will work better for different crops. For rice it has been found that wire loops should be used and the best spacing for these loops is approximately 40 mm apart and 60 mm high.<ref name=Singh/> This study was performed in the North Western Himalayan region of India. Loops are generally preferred for crops with small grains such as wheat, sorghum, pearl millet, etc. For corn/maize is it is suggested that solid spikes, 6 mm long, and spaced 200 mm apart be used.<ref name=Mtshali/> This study was done in Nigeria. Nails may be used as a rudimentary form of spikes.<ref name=Ebenezer/><ref name=Singh/> A cylinder without spikes or loops can be used if the grain is being ground against a surface. A model of this type was developed by the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] for a project in Guatemala.<ref name="Pedal Powered..."/> *A cover behind the cylinder is required to prevent grain from flying out of the machine while threshing.<ref name=Dewangan/> *Attachment of crank to cylinder with use of bolts and metal pieces.
==Pedal-powered threshers==
===Stationary pedal-system=== An addition that can be built to make a thresher more efficient is to make it pedal-powered. This adds two more parts: *A seat for the pedalling operator *Pedals that are attached to the crank with a chain and sprocket. The pedal-powered thresher developed by the Maya Pedal Project provides a good example of a built-in pedal system to a thresher/mill.<ref name="Pedal Powered..."/>
===Attachment to a bicycle=== An attachment to a regular bicycle can be built to allow the bike to be used as the seat, pedals, chain and sprocket of the thresher. The bicycle must be on a stand so that the back wheel is raised off the ground. Plans have been developed to build the attachment and the wheel-stand out of pieces of metal, including a large wheel that can be screwed to the crank section of the thresher (see External links).<ref name=Ebenezer/> A drill will be required to make this as well.
==Advantages== Advantages of the thresher include less physical labour and more efficiency (amount of grain thresher per amount of time).<ref name=Quisumbing/> Less seed breakage is also a benefit of using a thresher as opposed to stomping or beating grains.<ref name=Quisumbing/> However, more breakage can occur it is not used properly.
==Complications==
===Cultural=== Cultural differences must be considered.<ref name=Quisumbing/> Introduction of machinery to the threshing process, and the way that the pedal-powered thresher is used have conflicted with cultural beliefs or practices in some cases. The preferences of the region must be taken into consideration.<ref name=Quisumbing/>
===Injury=== There are physical dangers involved in introducing machinery into a farming process; one of these is injury to hands and arms when feeding the stalks into the thresher.<ref name=Dewangan/> When building the thresher, creating a higher hood/chute cover helps stop the operator’s hands from contacting the machine, but does not entirely eliminate the danger.<ref name=Dewangan/>
===Seed breakage=== Seeds can be broken and ruined as they go through the thresher, and seed breakage can happen more often with threshers that are the wrong size or design for the type of seed.<ref name=Mtshali/> The wire loops or spikes may have to be adjusted if seeds appear to be broken (''please see suggestion for spacing''). Seed breakage also happens with stomping and beating, however if the thresher is not built in an appropriate way for the specific grain, more breakage may occur. If the thresher is well-suited for the size of the grain and stalks, it should have fewer broken seeds than beating or stomping.<ref name=Quisumbing/> The most common seed breakage with threshers is with corn/maize, when there is too much moisture in the kernels.<ref name=Mtshali/> This can be reduced by drying kernels more thoroughly before threshing.<ref name=Mtshali/>
===Size/weight=== The size and weight of the thresher can be problematic. The thresher may need to be carried, and therefore must be light enough for one person. The suggested weight is 35 kg.<ref name=Nkakini/> On hillside farms it may be difficult to transport the thresher or to set it up properly.<ref name=Nkakini/>
==References== {{reflist|refs= <ref name=Dewangan>Dewangan 2010, p.560-73.</ref> <ref name=Ebenezer>Ebenezer (2013). "Technology for the poor". Retrieved October 21, 2013.</ref> <ref name=Mtshali>Mtshali 1998, p.23-25.</ref> <ref name=Nkakini>Nkakini 2007, p.1175-86.</ref> <ref name="Pedal Powered...">"Pedal Powered Water Pumps, Threshers, Blenders, Tile Makers and More" (2001). Retrieved October 21, 2012.</ref> <ref name=Quisumbing>Quisumbing 2012, p.581-92.</ref> <ref name=Singh>Singh 2008, p. 591-600.</ref> }}

''International Journal of Industrial Ergonomics'' 40(2010): 560-73. *Ebenezer, Job S., Ph.D. "Technology for the Poor". ''Technology for the Poor''. N.p., n.d. Web. 21 Oct. 2013. *Mtshali, Sazile.
